7.20 LIST OF AUTOMATION, ROMOTE CONTROL, INSTRUCTION AND GAUGE 364353

1    GENERAL PART

1.1    GENERAL DESCRIPTION

It is the intent of this Specification and the accompanying Plans to set forth the design, material, construction and equipment of a single screw diesel driven ocean going B-60 type bulk carrier with forecastle suitable for the transportation of coal and iron ore.


Following contract plans shall accompany and form an integral part of this Specification:


General Arrangement Plan (DWG No.180KBC-19103-GA-R1)

MidshipSection (DWG No.180KBC-19103-MS-R1)

Maker’s List (DWG.No. 180KBC-19103-ML-R1)


This Specification and accompanying plans shall form an integral part of the Shipbuilding Contract of the vessel.


The vessel to be designed, constructed, equipped, tested and delivered to the Buyer by the Builder in accordance with this Specification and Class/Buyer’s approval plans.


Details in design, fabrication, installation, inspection and workmanship not covered by this Specification and approval plans to be performed under the standard practice of the Builder.


Materials, machineries and equipments to be designed generally in accordance with Chinese Industrial Standard (GB), (CB)/(CBM) and/or the current maker's standards and Classification requirement, unless otherwise agreed or stated herein.


The Builder shall furnish all items required for the completion of the vessel in accordance with this Specification except items specifically stated herein as to be furnished and supplied by the Buyer.


It is to be understood that anything not mentioned in this Specification but required by the Classification Society or Regulatory Bodies listed herein, to be supplied and/or equipped by the Builder.


Any requirement of the Buyer, which is in excess of the requirements of the Rules and Regulations as specified in Section 1.6, "CLASSIFICATION RULES, REGULATIONS AND CERTIFICATES" and/or the content of this Specification, to be subjected to adjustment to the contract price, deadweight, etc., which may be effected. Such modification and changes to be mutually agreed in writing before the modification is carried out as per provisions in the Shipbuilding Contract.


Anything mentioned or enumerated twice or more in this specification is to be supplied or executed once only.


Regarding modification of the Specification, substitution of materials, and the supervision and inspection after signing of the Contract and/or during construction the Shipbuilding Contract is to be referred to.

If any inconsistency is found between the Contract and this Specification and/or this Specification and Plans, the former shall prevail and govern unless otherwise agreed.


If any inconsistency is found between the Hull, Machinery and Electric specification, the description of the specification which governs the installation or equipment shall prevail.


In the event of conflict or inconsistency between the Specifications and the drawings/plans/documents approved by the Buyer, the drawings/plans/documents approved by the Buyer shall prevail, but the Specifications shall prevail in respect of the number of equipment and existence of system only.


If there is non-conformity between the Specifications and the constructions or between the approved drawings/plans/documents by the Buyer and the constructions, the Buyer and the Builder shall discuss this matter upon the Builder’s request and shall make their best effort to solve with amicable cooperation.


In general, the figures concerning the capacity and the performance in the Specifications shall be considered as an “approximately”.


Whenever the term "or equal" is used after a brand or a type of machinery, equipment or component, the term "or equal" to be understood to mean that any substitute to be of reasonably equivalent standard and quality.


Whenever the term "option" is used it is understood that the choice rest with the Builder.


The descriptions with the terms such as “for reference”, or “generally” may relieve the Builder of its responsibilities to strictly conform to requirement embodied in such description.

All data and particulars in this Specification and the attached General Arrangement Plan are well estimated according to Builders' experience and best knowledge. They are believed to be correct but shall be subject to further detailed design and calculations.


Goods and parts supplied by sub-contractors and/or Buyer shall be properly and securely stored under cover and protected in the Builder’s premise, easily identified and traceable.


Workmanship as for the construction, material and equipment outfitting, shall be of good Chinese Shipbuilding Quality Standard (CSQS).


Stainless steel without grade notation in the Specifications shall mean JIS SUS304.


The Builder may make changes to the design and the arrangement for introduction of the improved production methods or design techniques or others during the building period with the Buyer’s approval, which shall not be unreasonably withheld by the Buyer.


All figures given in the Specifications shall be understood as approximate ones and determined in accordance with the design development except those which are of countable nature, unless otherwise specifically described in the Specifications.


1.2    GENERAL ARRANGEMENT

1.2.01General Arrangement


The vessel to be a type of Cape size single screw ocean going Bulk Carrier having one complete flush upper deck, with forecastle and stem, a transom stern and open water type of stern frame, a semi-balanced rudder and a fixed pitch propeller directly driven by a slow speed diesel engine.


All accommodations including navigation bridge and propulsion machinery to be located aft.

Double bottom to be extend between the fore peak bulkhead and the aft peak bulkhead.


The main hull of the vessel to be sub-divided into the following compartments as shown on the General Arrangement Plan:


(1)Forecastle


(2)Fore Peak Water Ballast Tank (a well to be provided for speed log and echo sounder transducers installation on the bottom), Void Space, Chain Locker.


(3)Cargo Space


Cargo holds to be constructed as single hull with side hopper , double bottom and top side tanks as shown on the General Arrangement Plan.


Side hopper to have a slope of approximately 45 degrees and topside tank to have the bottom slope of approximately 30 degrees, both against horizontal.


Vertical corrugated watertight bulkheads to be provided between cargo holds each with upper and lower stool.


No.1 hold forward and engine room front bulkhead to be of plain construction as shown on the General Arrangement Plan.


The cargo space to be divided into nine (9) holds.


(4)    Double Bottom Space


Double bottom to be provided in way of all cargo holds and engine room. The double bottom tanks to be used for water ballast in way of cargo hold. No.1 to 9 double bottom water ballast tanks are divided into port and starboard tanks by the pipe duct.


The double bottom tanks in way of cargo hold to be of hopper form throughout.


Pipe duct to be arranged at center line in way of No.1 to No.9 holds.


(5)Topside Wing Tanks


Topside Wing Tanks except in way of No.8&9Cargo Holds Topside Wing Tanks (P. & S.) to be used as water ballast tanks and to be connected to double bottom hopper tanks through trunks.


Fuel Oil Tanks to be arranged at Topside Wing Tanks in way of No.8&9Cargo Holds (P. & S.) with cofferdams at ship sides.


(6)Engine room


MGO Tank to be provided between Upper Deck and 2nd Deck with cofferdam at ship side.


Wash water tank to be provided in the double bottom of engine room and to be used for holding the fresh water from the fresh water generator. The fresh water to be used for cargo hold washing.


(7)Aft Peak Water Ballast tank, steering gear room, fresh water tanks, distilled water tank, rope store and emergency fire pump room.




1.2.02Loading Conditions of Cargoes


The vessel to be designed to be suitable for carrying coal and ore in bulk for worldwide services.


Alternate loading of ore cargo in holds No.1, 3, 5, 7 and 9 to be designed up to assigned summer draft.


Homogeneous load for all cargo holds shall be considered for heavy cargo with stowage factor of 3.0 mt/m3, with even percentage in each hold up to assigned summer draft.


All cargo hold bottom to be reinforced for grab discharging as per Rules’ recommendation without any special notation.


No. 6 Cargo Hold to be used as water ballast tank in case of heavy weather and constructed on the condition that it to be either full or empty when used as ballast tank at sea.


Cargo shall not be loaded in topside tanks.


Two ports loading/discharging to be considered for empty and full cargo holds in combination within suitable hull strength, but not dependant up on ballast adjustments as far as practicable.


The Nos.2, 4 & 8 Cargo Holds have been designed to be capable of partial ballast loading at port within the permissible level without any reinforcement for the convenience of loading/unloading cargoes.

1.3    MAIN PARTICULARS

1.3.01Principal dimensions, etc.


Length, overallabt. 292.00 m

Length between perpendiculars286.50 m

Breadth, moulded45.00 m

Depth, moulded24.90 m

Designed draft, moulded16.10 m

Scantling draft, moulded18.30 m


Erection and deckhouse height at centerline


Upper deck to Forecastle deck abt. 4.40 m

Upper deck to Boat deck3.00 m

Boat deck to A deck3.05 m

A deck to B deck3.05 m

B deck to C deck3.05 m

C deck to Captain deck3.05 m

Captain Deck to Nav.Bridge deck3.05 m

Nav. bridge deck to Compass deck        2.90 m


1.3.02.Sheer


On Forecastle deck            due to camber

On upper deckdue to camber


1.3.03Deck camber, Etc.


Upper Deck    840mm, straight camber at side and horizontal in the middle part. (1,980 mm from C.L.) for full breadth moulded.

    

Forecastle Deck    500 mm straight camber at side and horizontal in the middle part (1,980mm from C.L.) for full breadth moulded.


Compass Deck    abt. 100 mm straight camber at side and horizontal in the middle part (1,500 mm from C.L.)

                

NavigationBridge Deck (outside)    abt. 200 mm reverse straight camber for wings


Captain Deck (outside)    abt. 100mm, straight camber


Boat Deck (outside)    abt. 150mm, straight camber


Other decks (under upper deck)    Nil

1.3.04Deadweight, Capacity and Tonnage


    (1)    Deadweight:


On designed draft (mld) of 16.10 m

abt. 152,500 MT

in seawater of specific gravityof 1.025


On scantling draft (mld) of 18.30 m

abt. 180,000 MT

in seawater of specific gravityof 1.025


(2)    Capacity:


The cargo hold and tank capacities to be as follows:


Cargo hold            abt.     193,000m3

Water ballast tank (100% full)    abt.     79,500m3

(including No.6 ballast hold)

Heavy fuel oil tank (100% full)    abt.    4,200m3

MGO tank (100% full)        abt.    340m3

Fresh water tank (100% full)    abt.    470m3

Distilled water tank (100%full)abt.75m3


(3)    Tonnage:


Gross tonnage (International)    abt.    91,000

Net tonnage (International)    abt.    59,000


1.3.05Main engine,Speed, Fuel Consumption and Endurance


(1) Main engine


No. of set:                One (1)

Model:                     WIN GD W6X72-B Tier II/III

Output:

Maximum continuous output(MCR):    23,520kW × 89.0RPM

Contract max. continuous rating(CMCR):    14,436kW × 68.0 RPM

Continuous service rating(CSR):        10,683kW × 61.5RPM



(2)    Speed


Service speed at 74% of Contract max. continuous rating(CMCR) with 15% sea margin.


On design draft (mld) of 16.10 mabt. 14.2knots


The speed shall be guaranteed at above-mentioned engine output with clean hull in calm (no wind, no wave, no currents) and deep sea conditions with temperature of 15 deg Celsius.


For the deviations from the above-mentioned conditions during speed tests, the test results shall be corrected in accordance with ISO 15016: 2015 method.


The boss cap fin shall be considered as energy saving device.


(3)    Fuel Consumption

Main Engine fuel oil consumption per day at 74% of CMCR and lower calorific value of 42700kj/kg at ISO 3046-1 ambient reference condition and IMO NOx limitation for tier II / III.


abt. 39.6 MT (+ 6%) on tier II mode

abt. 39.6 MT (+ 6%) on tier III mode


(4)    Endurance


Endurance based on service speed of 14.2knots and main engine run at CSR with 15% S.M.

(on design draft), M/E + 1 G/E (running at CSR) consumption only to be considered.

abt. 25,000 N.M.


1.4     DEADWEIGHT, TRIM AND STABILITY

1.4.01Deadweight


The vessel shall have a deadweight carrying capacity of abt. 180,000 metric tons, in seawater of specific gravity of 1.025 on the scantling draft (mld) of abt. 18.30 m (mld).


The deadweight to be determined as a difference between total displacement at the scantling draft and the vessel's light weight. The total displacement to be calculated by the hydrostatic characteristic table, including shell and all appendages.


The vessel's light weight shall consist of the following items.


(1)    Hull, machinery and electrical weight including all equipment and fittings required by the Rules and Regulations and the specifications, but not including:


(a)    Spares over and above the Rules and Regulations and classification requirements.

(b)    All consumable stores.

(c)    Equipment, instruments, stores, etc., those which are furnished by the Buyer.

(d)    Men and their effects.

(e)    Oil and water in piping and tanks, but including lub. oil and cooling water in system.


(2)    Oil and water in main engine and auxiliary machinery all up to working level, but not including:


(a)    Fresh water in drain inspection and cascade tank, auxiliary condenser, fresh water pressure tank and composite boiler.

(b)    Salt water in auxiliary condenser.

(c)    Fuel oil in fuel oil settling tanks, service tank and overflow tank.

(d)    MGO in MGO settling tank and service tank.

(e)    Lubricating oil in L.O. sump tank and L.O. in storage tanks.

(f) Cylinder Oil in storage tank.

(g)    Oil and/or water contained in all drain tanks, sludge tanks and sewage tank.


The draft measurement for ascertaining the vessel's light weight to be carried out at the Builder's quay together with the inclining experiment. Inclining experiment may be carried out by means of ballast water shifting.


In case of the series vessels, the inclining experiment to be carried out only for the Builder’s first vessel of the standard design series. For subsequent vessels only deadweight measurement to be carried out.


Deadweight measurement and Inclining experiment at builders quay or in dock shall be carried in calm weather condition when the construction of the vessel is as complete as possible at the time of the test.


The calculation of the vessel's light weight and the resulting deadweight to be made by the Builders and approved by the Class.


The deadweight to be adjusted for any alteration by Buyers' requirement beyond the scope of this Specification.


1.4.02Trim and Stability


The vessel is to be designed so that the vessel shall trim approximately when loaded to the summer loaded draft, full bunkers, all stores, provisions, fresh and feed water on board at departure condition.


Possible trim adjustment by using ballast water to obtain approximately even keel at fully load arrival condition is allowed.


At the preliminary stage, the Builder is to submit trim and stability calculations to the Buyer at fully loaded, ballast and other necessary loading conditions intended for the ship's service as well as a preliminary capacity plan.


Trim and stability data to be calculated for the following conditions


(1) Fully loaded condition with homogeneous cargo to designed and scantling draft. Departure and Arrival.

(2) Full ore loading condition (SF=21 ft3/Lt) in alternative holds, (1, 3, 5, 7 and 9 cargo holds) to design and scantling draft. Departure and Arrival.

(3) Full ore loading condition (SF=11.96 ft3/Lt) in alternative holds, (1, 3, 5, 7 and 9 cargo holds) to design and scantling draft. Departure and Arrival.

(4) Homogeneously ore (SF=11.96 ft3/Lt) loaded at scantling draft in every hold.

(5) normal ballast condition. Departure and Arrival.

(6) Heavy ballast condition. Departure and Arrival.

(7) Docking condition.

(8) Light Ship Condition

(9) Multiport Loading Condition

(10) Ballast Exchange Sequence (including normal ballast condition)

(11) Propeller Afloat Condition

(12) Typical Loading and Unloading Sequence


For each calculation, bunker and other ship’s consumable supplies to be as follows:


The departure conditions are to be based on bunker tanks not taken less than 95% full and other consumables taken at 100% capacity.


The arrival conditions are to be based on 10% of the maximum capacity of bunker, fresh water and stores.


Loading condition to provided with Hold Mass Curves based on the design criteria for local strength, hold mass curves are to be included in the loading manual and the loading instrument, in sea-going condition and conditions of loading and unloading in port.


Trimmed hydrostatics shall be used for all conditions but not even keel hydrostatics.


Preliminary trim and stability calculations on various service conditions mutually agreed between the Buyer and Builder to be submitted to the Buyer and Class for approval.


If the final Trim and Stability Booklet is still under approval by the Classification Society or Authority at the time of ship delivery, the Class endorsed booklet to be used on a provisional basis.


The builder however to deliver the final Trim and Stability Booklet to the Buyer before the expiration of the provisional certificate.

1.5    RULES, REGULATIONS AND CERTIFICATES

1.5.01Rules and Regulations


The vessel, including its machinery and equipment, and outfitting to be constructed in accordance with the Rules and Regulations mentioned below and under the special survey of the following Classification Society and to be distinguished in the record by the classification symbol and notation:


LLOYD’S REGISTER


+100A1 , Bulk Carrier, CSR, BC-A, (holds 2,4,6 & 8 may be empty),ESP, ShipRight (CM, ACS (B)), GRB(35),*IWS, LI, +LMC, UMS, with descriptive Notes, ShipRight (BWMP(S), SCM)

or


BUREAU VERITAS


I +HULL, +MACH, Bulk Carrier, CSR, BC-A (maximum cargo density 3.0t/m3; holds 2, 4, 6 and 8 may be empty), ESP, Unrestricted navigation, +AUT-UMS, STAR-HULL,MON-SHAFT, INWATERSURVEY,GRAB[35],CPS(WBT)

or


AMERICAN BUREAU OF SHIPPING

+A1 (E), Bulk Carrier, BC-A (holds 2,4,6 & 8 may be empty), CSR, AB-CM, +AMS, +ACCU,RW,TCM,GRAB[35tonnes]，CPS, BWE, ESP, UNWILD, CRC, POT, PMA, RRDA, ESP


DET NORSKE VERITAS

+1A1 Bulk Carrier, ESP, CSR, ES, NAUTICUS (Newbuilding), Bulk Carrier, BC-A holds 2,4,6 & 8 may be empty, GRAB(35), EO, BIS, TMON, COAT-PSPC(B), OPP-F


The Vessel shall be built in compliance with the following Rules and Regulations and Requirement of the Authorities in force as of the date of the Contract signing together with all mandatory rules and regulations with amendment.


(1) National Maritime Regulations of Country of Registry.

(2)Rules and Regulations of the Classification Society (hereinafter called as "CLASS RULES")

(3)    Common Structural Rules for Bulk Carriers and Oil Tankers.

(4)Performance Standard for Protective Coatings for Dedicated Seawater Ballast Tanks in all Types of Ships and Double-side Skin Spaces of Bulk Carriers (PSPC) (Resolution MSC.215(82))

(5)    International Convention on load lines, 1966 (B-60 type vessel) and amendments 1988.

(6)    the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS) consolidated edition,2014, and all Amendments of contract date.

(7)    Convention on the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea, 1972 and related Amendments up to 2013.

(8)    International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973 and the Protocol of 1978 (Annex I, IV, V & VI) and latest relevant Amendments. (hereinafter called “MARPOL 73/78”)

(9)    International Convention on tonnage Measurement of ships, 1969.

(10)    The Suez Canal Rules of Navigation including Tonnage Measurement.

(11)    International Tele-communication Convention, 1973 and 1982 and Radio Regulations edition of 1982 revised in 1985 and 1993.

(12)    Australia Navigation (orders) Regulations for parts and provision handling cranes (excluding engine room overhead crane).

(13)    MLC 2006 title 3 Standard A 3.1 except swimming pool.

(14)    Requirement of Australian Waterside Worker's Federation (AWWF) for hold ladders. (without certificate but letter of approval from recognized authority or autorized agency should be submitted and drawings to be endorsed by authorized agents. )

(15)    MSC.337(91) Code on noise levels on board ships.(The personal protective equipment shall be provided by the Buyer)

(16)    International Maritime Pilots Association (IMPA) Recommendation for pilot ladder

(17)    International Code on Intact Stability, 2008(applicable part only)

(18)    International Maritime Solid Bulk Cargoes (IMSBC Code) (for coal only)

(19)    U.S. Coast Guard Rules and Regulations for foreign flag vessel, including fuel oil transfer facility, (CFR Title 33-part 155, 156, 159 and 164) and with letter of compliance but without certificate nor inspection.

(20)    International Convention on the Control of Harmful Anti-Fouling Systems on Ships, 2001.

(21)    International Convention for the Control and Management of Ship’s Ballast Water and Sediments, 2004.


IACS unified requirement to be applied only if it is mandatory at the time of signing the Shipbuilding Contract.


Yard will provide the ballast management plan with sequencial method to owner.


1.5.02Certificates


Following certificates to be issued (one original and two copies) and delivered to the Buyer at time of delivery unless mentioned otherwise.


(1) Tonnage Certificate for registration of the vessel (Class on behalf of RG.)

(2) Certificate of Classification (Class)

(3) International Loadline Certificate (Class on behalf of RG.)

(4) Safety Radio Certificate (Class on behalf of RG.)

(5) Safety Equipment Certificate (Class on behalf of RG.)

(6) Safety Construction Certificate (Class on behalf of RG.)

(7) Lifting Gear Certificate (including provision crane, engine room crane, elevator etc.) (Builder)

(8) Suez Canal Tonnage Certificate (Class)

(9) Deadweight Certificate (Builder)

(10) Builder's Certificate (Builder)

(11) Compass Adjustment Certificate (Builder)

(12) International Oil pollution prevention certificate (Class)

(13) Attestation of USCG (only for oil pollution and marine sanitation device) (Class).

(14) Report on chemical and bacteriological examination of the drinking water (CG).

(15) AWWF Approval letter for hold ladder and MUA examination letter for

access arrangement to cargo hold.

(16) Loading computer certificate by the class and loading instrument to be of Class type approval (only software not for hardware) with certificate, and test conditions to be verified by Class. (Class type approval to include strength and stability aspects.)

(17) Classification Certificate for anchor, anchor chains, machinery and equipment if required by the Class

(18) Statement of compliance for USCG for foreign flag vessel issued by the classification society.

(19) Certificates for lifeboat, life saving equipment and fire fighting equipment issued by the classification society or other assigned authority

(20) Certificates for navigation light and day signal lights by the classification society or other assigned authority.

(21) Crew accommodation certificates to ILO Convention 2006 issued by the classification.

(22) Certificate for carriage of bulk cargo in the IMSBC Code Appendix A, Appendix B (for coal only) and Appendix C issued by the classification.

(23) International Sewage Pollution Prevention Certificate or Statement (Class)

(24) Sanitary Inspection Certificate to be issued by Chinese Government

(25) Report for the pressure test for bunker line endorsed by Class

(26) Engine International Air Pollution Prevention Certificate (EIAPPC)

(27) SOPEP with class approval

(28) Ballast Water Management Plan

(29) Fire Control and Safety Plan

(30) Miscellaneous certificate for hull, machinery and outfitting, if requested by Class or recognized authorities.

(31) International Air Pollution Prevention Certificate (IAPPC)


Note:

1)    Abbreviation:

ClassClassification Society

CGChinese Government

RGRegistered Government


2)However, if formal certificates cannot be obtained at the ship's delivery, the Builder shall furnish provisional certificates to the Buyer, which substitutes the formal certificate.


In such case, the Builder shall deliver formal certificates to the Buyer which substitute the provisional certificates to the Buyer as soon as practicable after the ship's delivery. (But before the expiration of the provisional certificate)


1.6 FLAG


The ship shall be of convenient flag and registry, or equivalent.

1.8    BUYER SUPPLY

The following articles to be supplied by the Buyers to the Builder's yard at suitable time in accordance with the Builder's construction schedule.


The Buyers shall furnish beforehand plans, instruction books, test reports and test certificates, etc. of the equipment by the time designated by the Builders so that they can prepare for the work of the installation of the equipment.


Plans and instruction books for the equipment supplied by the Buyers shall not be furnished by the Builders.


(1)All bedding and linen (pillows, blankets, sheets, covers, etc.) but excluding mattresses.

(2)All napery (serviettes, tablecloths, etc.).

(3)All cook's and steward's utensils (crockery, cutlery, silverwares, earthenware, glasses, pots, pans, etc.).

(4)All chandlery (soaps, lamp oil, etc.).

(5)All paper charts, electronic charts, sailing books and flags.

(6)All consumable stores.

(7)All medicine and medical equipment.

(8)Recreational equipment other than mentioned in the Specification.

(9)Typewriter, computers, fax machine, copier and other office machines.

(10)Air tools and hoses in excess of those specified in this Specification.

(11)Hand tools other than specified in the Specification.

(12)Broadcasting radio receivers and stereophony (sockets installed by Builder).

(13)Film projector if any.

(14)Paintings, pictures and other decoration in accommodation space.

(15) TV, stereo, TV projector, VCD, radio/cassette unit, etc. such as hobby equipment.

(16)Suez searchlight.

(17)All brooms, brushes, vacuum cleaners, wastebaskets etc. for accommodation.

(18)Tow line and mooring lines other than those required by the regulation and specified in the Specification.

(19)All stationery.

(20) Boiler water testing kit and chemical compounds for the treatment of feed water and cooling fresh water.

(21) Garbage Cans.

(22) Wash deck hoses and fuel oil hose.

(23) Portable hold washing machine for holds (water tobey) if required.

(24) Portable vent fan for lower stool.

(25)Spare parts, navigation equipment, flags, etc., in excess of the requirements of the Rules and Regulations as specified herein, and/or those specified in the Specification.

(26)Water, fuel oil, lubricants and grease, working oil for deck machinery, all consumable liquid or gas, etc., to be of the Buyer's account excepting those which have been consumed in trials and tests, which are to be borne by the Builder.

(27) The Buyer shall supply lub. oil for sea trials and the Builder shall pay the cost for the quantities of lub. oil consumed during the trials.

(28)Portable measuring equipment for loading coal. (such as gas detector and PH-meter, etc.).

(29)    Ultrasonic level indicator for CO2 bottles.

(30) Shipboard oil pollution emergency plan (SOPEP) – all relevant technical information to be supplied by the Builder.

(31)Boatswain’s and carpenter’s tools in excess of Builder’s standard.

(32)Such items described as “Buyer’s supplies or equivalent” in the Specification.

    

Note: Buyer furnished equipment specified on other pages shall also be governed by these provisions.

1.9MATERIALS, WORKMANSHIP AND STANDARD UNIT

1.9.01Material


Materials, machineries and equipments, etc., to be of Chinese made or being imported to be supplied at Builder's selection and discretion unless otherwise agreed and/or described in the Specification.


Structural steel material of main hull structure to be the quality as required by the Classification Society and free from crack, laminationporosity and similar defects.


If any material described in the Specification cannot be obtained under certain circumstances, the Builder will have the right to substitute suitable equivalent material with Buyer's approval.


All wood should be well seasoned.

1.9.02Workmanship


All workmanship entering into the construction of the vessel to be in accordance with the Builders' standard practice and subject to the approval of the Classification Society where necessary.

1.9.03Standard


The following standards to be applied to the construction of the vessel, as far as practicable.


%3) Chinese Industrial Standard (GB)

%3) Chinese Shipbuilding Standard (CB)/(CBM)

%3) Chinese Metallurgical Standard (YB)

%3) Chinese Machinery and Electric Standard (JB)

%3) China Shipbuilding Quality Standard (CSQS)


The ISO standard to be applied as far as possible.

1.9.04Unit of Measure


Metric system to be adopted for design and construction of hull, machineries, equipments, etc. in general.


All measuring units such as power, pressure gauge, thermometer, volume gauge, tank scales, etc., to be in accordance with metric system.

1.10    PLANS, ETC.

1.10.01Plans for Approval


The scope of plans for submission to the Buyer for approval to be in accordance with “Approval Drawing List” which to be submitted to the Buyer after the Shipbuilding Contract in accordance with Builder’s standard. The “Approval Drawing List” to be subject to Buyer’s approval.


The Builder will submit plans to the Buyer in three (3) copies for approval and the Buyer shall return one (1) copy of the plans to the Builder with the Buyer's signature and comment if any.


All plans for approval to be written in English.


The Buyer shall return the approved plans within 21 days with Buyer’s authorized signature after receipt of the plans excluding the mailing time. All the return drawings shall be sent by Courier Service at Buyer’s cost.


If the Buyer fails to return the plans with Buyer’s authorized signature and/or to send any comments to the Builder within the said period, the Builder shall deem that these plans have been automatically approved.


No returned plan shall be marked as “rejected or not approved” without comment or because part of which has been commentd by the Buyer. It is to be undertaken that any content and/or part of such plans with no comments by the Buyer shall be deemed as approved upon return even if no buyer’s signature is endorsed on the plan in question.


1.10.02Finished Drawings


Upon delivery of the vessel, finished drawings in accordance with the standard form and type of the Builder and sub-contractors to be furnished to the Buyer in four (4) copies (2 for the ship and 2 for the Buyer).


The scope of the finished drawings to be as per Builder's standard.


All finished drawings to be written in English.


All finished drawings to be of white printout, the soft copy of "pdf" format shall include list of drawings, pricinple particulars, list of equipment with its capacity, maker and contacts as per Makers’ list.


The following plans shall be provided in frames and placed on board of the Vessel at such locations as designated by the Buyer's representative or the Rule regulations:

(1)    General Arrangement Plan

(2)    Capacity Plan with Deadweight Scale

(3)    Pumping Plan（including Fuel/lub. Oil transfer system and bilge/ballast system plan）

(4)    Fire control and safety Plan

(5)    Instruction of Life Jacket (one for each deck in accommodation and engine control room)

(6)    Safety Radio Telegraphy Certificate

(7)    Manoeuvring information diagram

(8)    Harbor speed plate (at main engine control console and wheelhouse)

(9)    Radar blind zone diagram


1.10.03Instruction Books


The Builder to collect instruction books according to maker’s standard complete with spare parts list, pamphlets and drawings from supplier and contractors.


Four (4) sets of instruction books and maker information to be furnished to the Buyer, two for the ship and two for the Buyer.


1.10.04Maker’s Information


Information including name of maker, postal address, telephone number, fax number and E-Mail Address for each equipment and machinery fitted onboard to be prepared in a booklet and delivery to the Buyer at time of delivery.

1.11    HULL FORM AND MODEL BASIN TEST

1.11.01Hull Form


The Builder is to design the hull form, propeller and rudder suitable for the vessel's speed and performance.


1.11.02ModelBasin Test(for first veseel of the series only)


The model basin test to be carried out for the following items:


(1) resistance test at design,scantling and ballast trial drafts.

(2) Self propulsion test at design, scantling and ballast trial drafts.


The test results shall be submitted to the Buyer for reference only.


1.11.03Ship Model


One set of exhibition model (length about 1.50m) to be supplied by the Builder to Buyer designated office.






1.12    INSPECTION, TEST AND TRIAL

During the building and construction of the vessel, the Buyer have right to send authorized representatives to the Builder’s yard to supervise and inspect the execution of work.


A list of inspection items to be mutually agreed between the Buyer and the Builder.


1.12.01Construction Inspection and Test


Test and inspection of hull structure to be conducted in accordance with the requirement of the Classification Society, Regulatory Bodies and the practice of the Builder.


Steel structures to be inspected and watertightness to be tested as required by the Class Rules.


1.12.02Shop Trial.


Major machinery to be tested at the makers’ shops in accordance with the Class Rules in order to verify their performance in accordance with the specification. For safety device test, actual measurement or simulation shall be carried out as per maker’s standard. For test onboard the Machinery Part shall be referred to.


The guarantee fuel consumption of the main engine to be certified at the shop trial of the main engine.


Shop tests shall be carried out for the machinery and equipment by the manufacturers at their shops. Test results of major machinery and equipment shall be furnished to the Owner in triplicate. The Owner shall be informed of the shop test schedule at least fourteen(14) days for foreign maker (outside China) and seven(7) days for domestic maker in advance of the expected date of the shop tests and the owner's attendance shall be confirmed to the Builder.


1.12.03Onboard Test


In general the onboard tests, test times etc. to be in accordance with the Rules and Regulations and Builder’s standard where applicable.


1.12.04Mooring Trial


Mooring tests to be conducted after the vessel is completed and prior to the sea trial. Procedure for mooring test of the vessel to be as per Builder's standard.


Quay trial for the main engine shall be carried out to check the running of main engine and associated auxiliary machineries prior to the sea trial according to the Builder’s practice while the Vessel is moored at quay.


1.12.05Sea Trials


(1)    Official Sea Trial


When the vessel is substantially completed except minor items of work and after successful mooring trial, sea trial to be conducted at a draft and trim determined by the Builder approximately equivalent to the ballast condition tested in the model basin.


The procedure of sea trial to be prepared in accordance with the Builder’s practices and submitted to the Buyer for reference.


The time schedule for the official sea trial shall be informed to the Buyer for reference in accordance with the provision in the Shipbuilding Contract.


Heavy fuel oil (of viscosity obtainable in Shanghai, China) is to be used during the sea trial except otherwise specified.


The vessel is to be ballasted approximately to the model test ballast condition and following trials to be performed.


(2)Progressive Speed Trial


For the Builder’s first vessel of series,progressive Speed Trial to be performed at 65% load of CMCR, C.S.R， 75%load of CMCR, and CMCR of the main engine or the output corresponding to the allowable shaft revolutions of the engine, whichever is reached first.


For subsequent vessels of the series, progressive Speed Trial to be performed at ，C.S.R, 75% load of CMCR ,SMCR of the main engine or the output corresponding to the allowable shaft revolutions of the engine, whichever is reached first..


The trial speeds are to be measured by D.G.P.S. trial system and the shaft power to be measured by torsionmeter.


Each speed trial is to consist of two consecutive runs of one nautical mile each, along and against the tide over the same course and the speed to be obtained as the mean speed of the consecutive runs.


Result of speed trials shall be corrected to the calm water condition (no wind, no wave,no currents) and deep sea according to ISO 15016:2015 method.


(3)    Main Engine Starting Test

(4)Anchoring Test

(5)Crash Stop Astern and Crash Stop Ahead Test (for the Builder’s first vessel of series only)

(6)Turning Test (for the Builder’s first vessel of series only)

(7)Steering Gear Test

(8)Z-maneuver test (for the Builder’s first vessel of series only)

(9)Endurance Trial（To be according to Class Rule’s requirement.）

(10)Fuel Oil Consumption Test of M/E shall be measured for one(1) hour at CSR during the endurance trial for reference.

(11)Adjustment of Magnetic Compass

(12)    Composite Boiler Evaporation Test by M/E Exhaust Gas at CSR

(13)Inertia Test (for the Builder’s first vessel of series only)

(14)Minimum Shaft RPM Test:

(15)Torsional Vibration Test (for the Builder’s first vessel of series only)

(16)    Fresh Water Generator Capacity Test at CSR

(17)Vibration according to section 1.13 "Noise and Vibration" measurement of engine room and accommodation space. (for the Builder’s first vessel of series only)

(18)Noise level measurement in accommodation and engine room.

(19)Unmanned machinery space test

(20)Echo sounder test

(21)Black-out and Recovery test

(22)Safety device test for main engine

(23)Program up and cancel test (bridge control during endurance test)

(24)Stand-by pump auto start test

(25)Electric Load Measurement (for record only) (for the Builder’s first vessel of series only)

(26)Operation Test of Navigation Equipment and Radio Equipment

(27)Fire Detection and Alarm Test

(28)Williamson Turn Test(for the Builder’s first vessel of series only)

(29)Dead ship recovery(for the Builder’s first vessel of series only)

(30) Speed Log test and adjustment

(31) Safety valve poping test of composite boiler

(32) HFO, MGO change over test and Low Sulfer Fuel Oil system function test which use with MGO instead of Low sulfur fuel oil


1.12.06 Overhauling


After sea trial, working parts of main engine to be opened for the Buyer's inspection in accordance with the standard of the Builder and refitted to working condition.


One cylinder unit to be overhauled as following:


- One cylinder unit overhauling

- One main bearing to be opened up and lower shell to be moved out for inspection.

- One connect rod bearing to be opened up.

- One cross head bearing to be opened up


A confirmation run after overhaul for 1/2 hour at low load to be carried out before delivery.


Tests and adjustments of nautical instruments to be performed during the trial trips or at other convenient time.


Report of official sea trial including all data and results to be submitted to the Buyer.


1.13    NOISE AND VIBRATION

1.13.01Noise


Noise levels to comply with IMO MSC.337(91) —“Code on Noise Levels on Board Ship, 2012” except swimming pool area where the noise level shall not be considered if arranged.


Noise levels to be measured by the Builder at the suitable points when the vessel is running ahead steadily when main engine power at CSR or 80% CMCR, which is greater during sea trial.


If the noise level exceeds 3 dB(A) above the specified value, the builder shall make necessary improvement to a practicalextent mutually agreed between the owner and builder.


Noise level limits of major space to be as follows:


- Machinery space                110    db (A)

- Engine Control Room                75    db (A)

- Wheelhouse including Chart Space        65    db (A)

- Private cabins and hospital            55    db (A)

- Mess, recreation rooms, offices and Gymnasium    60    db (A)

- Galley and pantry                75    db (A)

(no food processing equipment operating)

- Workshops                    85    db (A)

1.13.02Vibration


The International standard ISO 6954-2000(E) to be used as a criteria in the accommodation and working areas.


The vibration level in living quarters of the vessel to be measured by the Builder when the vessel is running ahead steadily when main engine speed at specified RPM of CSR,during the sea trial.


In the event that the actual measured vibration exceed the above mentioned level, necessary counter measure to be make to an extent mutually agreed between the Buyer and the Builder.


Shaft alignment and torsion vibration check shall be carried out in corporation with engine builder, and report submit to buyers for reference.

1.14    SPARE PARTS AND TOOLS


Obligatory spare parts and tools for equipment and machinery required by the Class Rules and standard spares and tools supplied by the maker and spare parts and tools specified in the Specification to be furnished by the Builder.


Additional spare parts and tools required by the Buyer to be supplied by the Builder only after written agreement has been reached between the Buyer and Builder regarding extra cost to be paid by the Buyer.

1.15    DRYDOCKING AND DELIVERY

1.15.01Drydocking


In the event that the period between the delivery date and the launching of the vessel is more than 6 months for the vessel, an underwater survey shall be carried out at the builder’s expense.


1.15.02Delivery


When completed, the vessel including delivery documents, certificates, finished drawings, spare parts inventories which are signed for receipt by ship and stowed in place by builders, to be delivered to the Buyer in a seaworthy condition, safely afloat at the Builder's wharf under the requisite legal formalities.


Tanks, cargo holds, bilges, accommodation and other spaces to be free from dunage and dirt, completed in every respect and ready for service. Cargo holds to be free from residue water, bilge and sludge holding tanks to be empty as far as possible.


Painted surfaces to be touched up and cleaned and dried, machineries to be in running order, all electric lights to be in good working order, outfits, spares and stores to be properly stowed, and compass and other nautical and communication equipment to be adjusted and ready for service. All deck and engine room grease points/oil points to be properly greased or lubricated.

2    HULL PART

2.1    HULL CONSTRUCTION

2.1.01General


Scantlings and arrangements of the hull structure to be determined in accordance with Common Structural Rules for Bulk Carriers and Oil Tanks (CSR) and the requirements of the Classification Society.


All steel hull to be of welded construction.


2.1.02Material and Scantling


(1)    Material


Steel of hull construction to be of mild steel and high tensile steel. Higher tensile steel (315N/mm2 and/or 355N /mm2 minimum yield stress) to be used for the main hull structure in general.


Welding consumables are to comply with the Classification Society requirements.


Special strengthening of hull structure more than the approved drawings by the Classification Society is generally not to be provided except otherwise mentioned in the Specification or to be considered as the extra work on the Buyer's account, as long as the work will not disturb the Builder’s working schedule.


Steel material not specified by the Classification Society to be in compliance with the Chinese Standard (GB, CBM and YB).


All frames, beams and stiffeners to be of rolled section, built-up section or flat bar.


Application of steel grade to be in accordance with the requirement of the Classification Society.


Steel of hull construction to be of mild steel or high tensile steel approved by the Classification Society, and steel including casting and forging to be of qualities as complying with the requirements of the Classification Society.


(2)    Scantling


Scantling to be based on the ship’s scantling draft (mld) and according to the Class Rules.


Except for those otherwise mentioned herein, the scantlings of all the structural members should meet the requirement of the Classification Society.


The scantling not specified by the Classification Society to be in accordance with the Builder’s practice.


2.1.03Workmanship


Works to be executed in accordance with the Builders' construction practice and under the surveyor of the Classification Society and Buyer supervisor.


For all flat bars or built up T sections in water ballast tanks, the free edges to be treated according to PSPC requirement.


Builder's and Maker's Quality Standard to be applied for the workmanship of hull construction and outfitting.


2.1.04Electric Welding


The hull is to be of all welded construction.


Welding to be executed in accordance with the Builders' practice approved by the Classification Society except unimportant or attachment welding which to be carried out as per Builder's practice.


Manual, semi-automatic and automatic welding methods including one side welding to be applied as per Builder's practice.


All welding for the main hull and superstructure exposed to weather or wet space to be of double continuous fillet welding for stiffening webs, stiffeners, frames. Intermittent welding may be used for internal structure of superstructure for ordinary beams, frames and stiffeners in dry space.


Corrective measures for mis-cut holes, lack of alignment of joints and excessive gaps between surface of edges, etc., to be applied subject to the approval by the Classification surveyor and Buyer’s supervisor.


In order to ascertain the soundness of welding, suitable numbers of X-ray photograph to be taken for the important members according to the rule requirement. Numbers and positions of X-Ray test plan to be agreed with buyers supervision in charge, and the test plan shall keep under control without open to welding workers.


All such X-ray photographs to be presented to and checked by the Classification surveyor and Buyer’s supervisor.


Clamps, dogs and other suitable devices as per the Builders' practice to be applied for execution of welding so as to place the material into adequate position.


2.1.05Access Opening and Temporary Pieces


Temporary access openings may be provided on shells, bulkheads, decks, walls, etc. for convenience of works and to be closed in place by welding and inspected by Class Surveyor and Buyer Supervisor.


A plan for access opening to be submitted for confirmation beforehand.


Dogs, eyeplates and clamps etc. used for the erection to be left in space if it is not obstructing any operation. Others to be cut and grind smooth.


Any undercut found in way to be built up with welding.


Temporary lifting eye plate and pieces welded during construction in cargo hold, on exterior shell and on deck to be removed. Others to be remained or removed as per Builder’s practice.


2.1.06Slots, Scallops and Holes


Slots, scallops, air holes and drain holes to be provided where necessary in accordance with the Builder's practice.


Generally, non-tight structural members are to be provided with adequate access/lightening holes in accordance with the Builder's practice, provided such holes are necessary or practicable and not detrimental to the structural strength of members.


2.1.07Structure and Tightness Test


Structural and tightness tests to be carried out in accordance with the Builder's practice which is in line with the requirement of Classification Society and in the presence of Class Surveyor.


In general the leak test to be carried out by air using detective reagent soapy water with the agreement of the Classification surveyor.


Structure strength test to be carried out for tanks selected by Classification surveyor by filling with water at afloat condition or in dry dock to ensure integrity of tank boundary.

2.2    MAIN HULL STRUCTURE

2.2.01General


The scantling, construction and materials of hull within a range of midship part to be as shown on the Midship Section Plan.


Hull construction to be designed at the scantling draft (mld) and to be of all welded construction.


The structural work to be executed in accordance with the Builder's standard practice.


All connections of frames, beams, bulkhead stiffeners, etc., to brackets to be carefully managed to keep continuous welding around ends of brackets.


Adequate drain holes and air holes to be provided in the internal structural members of all tanks, engine room floors and longitudinals to ensure free movement of contents to suction and air to vents.


Reinforcement for docking to be considered according to Classification requirement.


Opening in the shell plating, deck girders etc to be rounded and reinforced where necessary.


Decks under machinery, bollards, boat davits and other heavy concentrated loads to be reinforced by carling and/or insert plate or welded doubler where necessary as approved by Class.


2.2.02Framing


In general, main part of the hull to be framed as follows:


(1)    Longitudinal Framing:


- Double bottom and hopper tanks in way of cargo holds

- Upper deck

- Topside tanks

- Side shell in way of engine room (partly)

- Fore peak tank (partly)


(2)    Transverse Framing:


- Side shell in way of cargo hold

- Forecastle deck

- Deckhouse

- Side shell in way of engine room (partly)

- Double bottom in way of engine room

- Aft peak tank (partly)

- Upper deck between hatches


2.2.03Keel Plate


The keel to be of flat plate throughout and is to be efficiently connected to the stem and stern frame.


2.2.04Stem


Stem to be of fabricated welded steel construction throughout with well-rounded forward edge, carefully formed to obtain fair connections to the hull lines, and welded to the shell and keel plates.


The shell plate in way of anchor path and bow to be of extra thickness to avoid damage in accordance with the Class Rules.


2.2.05Stern Frame


Stern form to be of open water type having an adequate propeller aperture.


Stern frame to be of fabricated steel plate welded construction with the propeller boss and rudder horn of cast steel. Stern tube to be of fabricated steel plate welded construction.


Stern frame to be welded to shell and keel as per Class requirement.


Cast steel to be annealed before fabrication, but fabricated construction shall not be annealed.


2.2.06Bottom Construction


Cellular double bottom to be constructed under cargo holds and engine room.


A watertight pipe duct to be fitted at centerline in way of No. 1 to No. 9 cargo holds.


The inner bottom in the cargo holds to be horizontal with hopper-shaped sides having inclination of about 45o to the horizontal except at upper part in way of fore and aft holds where the shape of the vessel may change the inclination.


Inner bottom plate in way of cargo holds to be strengthened according to the requirements of the Class Rules for grab discharge. Reinforcement for grabs to be as per Rules’ recommendation.


Bottom shells and inner bottom plates to be stiffened by bottom and inner bottom longitudinal respectively in way of cargo holds and solid floors in engine room.


The bottom forward to be strengthened and designed in accordance with the requirement of the Classification Society.


Forward structure will be designed and strengthened for lightest ballast draft at forward perpendicular for normal ballast conditions.


Transverse floors to be fitted at every third frame in cargo space except under lower stool and longitudinal girders under cargo holds to be arranged as required by the Class Rules.


Transverse floors in engine room to be fitted at every frame space and side girders to be arranged at suitable positions to suit the seating of the main engine.


2.2.07Engine Room


Engine room side shell to be stiffened partly by longitudinal framing and partly by transverse framing. Widely spaced substantial pillars to be arranged in conjunction with substantial web frames and web beams.


Cofferdam to be provided between the side shell and the heavy fuel oil tank and marine gas oil tank.


2.2.08Fore and Aft End


Fore peak tank to be used as water ballast tank and void space and built with transverse and/or longitudinal framing system.


Perforated longitudinal wash plate with vertical stiffeners to be provided at upper half in fore peak tank along the vessel's centerline.


Aft peak tank to be used as water ballast tank and constructed with transverse framing.


Steering gear room above aft peak tank to be constructed with transverse and/or longitudinal framing system.


2.2.09Shell plating


Thickness of the shell plate to be as per Class Rules.


Transverse framing system without web frame to be adopted for the cargo hold side shell as shown on the Midship Section Plan.


Shell plate in way of hawse pipe and anchor rubbing area to be reinforced with thicker plate as per the Builder’s practice.


Shell plates in way of tug pushing area to be reinforced by fitting of stiffenersto meet fifty (50) ton thrust force of tugs.


Stem throughout to be of fair-formed steel plate construction, well raked forward with round face.


Sheer strake to be connected to the deck stringer plate by welding as shown on the Midship Section Plan.


Opening of shell such as sea chest to be in accordance with the Class Rules.


Frog Eye to be provided for anchor resting. Structure of frog eye type anchor rest to be specially reinforced against heavy sea impact.


2.2.10Deck plating


The gunwale construction on upper deck to be of square type as shown on the Midship Section plan.


Partial deck and platform in the engine room to be of non-watertight construction.


Decks to be locally strengthened by stiffeners, carlings and/or insert plate or doublers under deck machinery, mooring fittings etc. where necessary.


Slant plates to be provided at the corners of cargo hatches.


Protection half round bar to be fitted on upper portion of top-side tank plates,hatch end beams and the upper portion of hatch coaming.

2.2.11Top side Tank


Top side water ballast tanks to be arranged at the shoulder part of the cargo holds and to be connected to the double bottom water ballast tanks except in way of No.8(part) &No.9 cargo holds which are to be used as heavy fuel oil tanks.


The topside tanks to have a slope of about 30o to the horizontal.


The topside ballast tanks to be connected with the lower hopper/double bottom water ballast tanks by trunks without segregation.


2.2.12Bulkhead


Transverse bulkhead to be arranged as shown on the General Arrangement Plan.


The forward collision bulkhead and the forward and aft bulkhead of engine room to be of plain type with vertical stiffeners supported by horizontal girders where necessary.


The stiffeners of the bulkheads at fore peak tank, engine room, aft peak tank to be arranged inside the compartment.


The engine room forward bulkhead to be slant forward below 2nd deck in engine room for arrangement of piping.


Transverse watertight bulkheads between cargo holds to be of vertical corrugated bulkheads with partly slant upper and lower end stools.


Corrugated bulkheads to be mounted on lower stools and slant top plates to be fitted at the lower ends of the corrugations to avoid accumulation of bulk cargo. Upper stools to be provided at the top part of the corrugated bulkhead under upper deck.


Transverse bulkheads in No. 6 cargo hold which are designed for dual purposes as cargo hold and fully filled water ballast hold during heavy ballast condition to be constructed of vertical corrugation with upper and lower end stools.


Part of the lower stool in NO.5 and No.6 cargo holds to be used as water ballast tank.


Three (3) watertight access trunks to be installed on corrugated bulkheads from upper stools to lower stools for access to pipe duct in way of cargo holds as shown on the General Arrangement Plan.


Other bulkheads to be of steel welded construction of flat plate type and to be of water, oil, gas tight, or non-watertight depending upon their intended purposes.


2.2.13Frame, Beam and Stiffener


Frames and beams to be of flat bars or rolled sections or built-up sections.


Frames, beams and stiffeners in tanks, cargo holds and engine room shall be double continuous welded.


Frames, beams and stiffeners in accommodation deckhouse to be intermittently welded in general except for wet spaces and on weather deck where continuous welding to be complied.


2.2.14Pillars and Girder


No pillar to be arranged in the cargo holds.


In engine room and steering gear room, web frames in conjunction with web beams and pillars to be provided at adequate spacing.


2.2.15Hatch Coaming


Coamings for cargo hatches to be suitably stiffened by stays and horizontal top rail. The coamings to be constructed to act efficiently as hatch end beams and hatch side girders. The height of the coamings to be about 1,000 mm at the central of upper deck.


2.2.16Superstructure and Deckhouse


Forecastle


The forecastle deck to be of transverse construction with suitably space deck girders and web beams. Deck plate in way of deck machinery to be strengthened in accordance with Class Rules.


Deckhouse


(1)    Deck:


Decks of the deckhouse to be of steel welded plating stiffened with beams and girders, and the thickness of the plating to be as per the Class Rules.


(2)    Steel Wall:


Flat plates with stiffeners to be applied for the external accommodation house walls.


The thickness of the outside steel wall plating to be of 6 mm at least.


Flat plates with stiffeners or corrugated steel walls to be applied for the construction of inside walls including corridor steel bulkheads, commissary spaces, refrigerating provisions space, battery room, paint store, sanitary space (except private lavatories) and other specified stores, etc.


Walls to be welded to other members and to be of water or gas tight or non watertight depending upon their intended purposes.


The thickness of the divisional steel walls to be of 6 mm at least.


2.2.17Engine Casing and Funnel


The engine Casing to be separated from the deckhouse to provide lower noise level in accommodation. A walkway to be provided between the B-deck and the engine casing top each at P & S side as shown on the General Arrangement Plan.


A funnel to be placed on the top of the engine casing and to be of steel plate with vertical stiffeners of angle bars. Top plate to be provided for the funnel. Suitably spaced horizontal stringers to be provided for the funnel body.


The exhaust gas pipes to be continuous upwards about 1.0 meter over the top of the funnel with a backward bend.


Louver to be provided on back part of funnel for engine room ventilation.


Steel lugs for painting steps to be provided at top of the funnel (outside).


2.2.18Miscellaneous


(1)    Foundation:

Foundation of main engine to be constructed as a part of double bottom construction.


Deck machinery and equipment as well as auxiliary machinery in engine room to be generally provided with foundation of steel welded construction with suitable re-inforcement under if required.


(2)    Bulwark

Bulwark of about 1,000 mm high to be provided for forward part of Forecastle deck.


Bulwark on navigation bridge deck at side to be of 1,100 mm height with bulb plate on top and front bulwark forming wind reflector to be 1,470 mm height with galvanized steel pipe handrail at suitable height.


No wooden top rail to be fitted.


(3)    Breakwater:

No breakwater to be fitted.


(4)    Bilge keel:


The discontinuous type bilge keel to be fitted for about 25% of LBP amidships on both sides of the vessel and consist of flat plate web with a flat bar reinforced at outside edge, welded to the bilge shell plate on a continuously over the whole length rider flat as shown on the Midship Section Plan.


(5)    Chain Locker:

Self-stowing chain lockers to be provided and extended to Forecastle Deck.


Surrounding bulkhead of each chain locker to be stiffened from outside.


Watertight access hatch to be provided on chain locker wall in forecastle space and means to be provided for access.


Bilge wells with perforated steel plates to be provided at the bottoms of the chain lockers.


No wooden sheathing to be fitted.


Bitter end of chain cable to be secured to a quick releasing device fixed on the sidewall of the chain locker in forecastle space. And to be watertight from forecastle space. Watertight access hatch is to be secured by closely spaced bolts.


(6)    Bilge wells:


Two bilge wells to be provided for each cargo hold at aft end.


Hold bilge well to be constructed with cascade system and provided with perforated plate.


The thickness of the surrounding walls to be in accordance with the Class Rules.


Watertight covers to be provided for bilge wells in No.6 hold and to be used when ballasting. The watertight covers to be common use for bilge well and ballast well.


(7) Ballast Wells


    Two (2) ballast wells to be provided in No. 2, 4, 6, 8 hold. The thickness of the surrounding walls to be in accordance with the Class Rules.


Flush watertight cover to be provided for each of the ballast well when dry cargo is carried in the holds.


(8)    Sea Chests


In the engine room one (1) high sea chest and one low sea chest to be provided. One (1) sea chest for the emergency fire pump to be arranged at the stern in stern tube cooling water tank and to be positioned at normal ballast condition.


Sea Chest openings to be shaped so as to avoid reinforcement of shell platings and/or fitted with doublers if required by the Classification Society.


Air escape holes and drain holes to be provided on side shell.


Holes for drainage and air escape shall be arranged at the lower and upper parts of the side shell plate.


Hinged strainer plate of stainless steel to be provided for each sea chest with a clear area of at least 2 times the cross section area of all the sea suctions connected to the sea chest. Bolts, nuts and hinge pins to be of stainless steel 316。


For the cathodic protection of sea chest refer to section 2.5 MGPS.


Anti-corrosive AL anode of 5-year life to be provided inside each sea chest.


(9)    Deck Store


A steel deck store of 2.70 m high with a collapsible light post shall be provided between No.4 and 5 hatches.

2.3    PAINTING

2.3.01General


Painting works including surface preparation, shop priming and inspection shall be carried out in accordance with the Builder’s practice and the paint manufacturer’s recommendation based on the Specifications.


For the dedicated seawater ballast tanks, painting works shall be done in accordance with the IMO Res. MSC.215(82) Performance Standard for Protective Coating of dedicated seawater ballast tanks (PSPC).


The Builder shall provide a coating inspector certified to NACE Coating Inspector Level 2 or FROSIO Inspector Level III or equivalent as verified by the Classification Society as required by PSPC.


Paint specifications shall be submitted to the Buyer for approval.


The color of finish coats of the hull shall be informed by the Buyer, but colors for each coat other than finish coat shall be in accordance with the paint manufacturer’s recommendation bearing in mind the color of finish coat.


No paint shall be applied to the following items or spaces unless otherwise specified.

- Copper, brass, bronze, aluminum, aluminum alloy and other non-corrosive metals.

- Wooden work in stores and lockers.

- Galvanized steel and fittings’ invisible parts

- Polished fittings.

- Inner surface of steel surface enclosed tightly.

- Internal steel decks covered with deck covering.


Painting for the equipments and machineries shall be carried out according to each manufacturer’s standard and the damaged part after installation shall be repaired, which is equivalent to the original.


In general, the outside of steel outfitting including pipes to be painted with one (1) coat of the Builder’s standard primer before installation and one (1) coat of finish paint same as surroundings after installation unless otherwise specified in this Specification. For the invisible parts of the pipes outside under U-bolts or pipe supports, only one (1) coat of Builder’s standard primer to be applied before installation and no more coating to be applied after installation.


Painting works for the parts or spaces which are not specified this Specification, shall be similar to surroundings or comparable spaces.


2.3.02Surface preparation


(1) Primary Surface Preparation


Steel plates and sections (6mm thickness and above) for hull structure shall be shot blasted to Sa21/2 (ISO 8501-1) and immediately primed with one (1) coat of inorganic zinc silicate shop primer to dry film thickness, which according to Paint Manufacturer’s data sheet.

Steel plates and sections (below 6mm thickness) for hull structure which are considered to be impractical for grit blasted may be treated by power tool cleaning.

The steel surface of fittings such as pipes, masts, pipe supports, grating supports, machinery seats, etc. to be generally power tool cleaned or pickled, then applied the standard primer.


At assembly shops, as soon as the completion of welding, the welding beads and parts where shop primer damaged shall be cleaned and touch up with shop primer less than approximately30 microns of D.F.T. for temporary protection.


The free edges of structural members and holes (slots, scallops, drain holes, air holes, etc.) in the dedicated water ballast tank shall be treated as PSPC’s requirement. In Other area, the free edges shall be treated as Builder’s practice.


(2)    Secondary surface Preparation


Prior to the first coat:


Damaged area on shop primed steel due to burning and welding during fabrication shall be treated according to “The table of surface treatments for damaged areas”, however intact shop primed areas which are allowed by paint manufacturer shall be retained, thereafter painted with first coat.


The visible zinc salts on intact shop primed surface shall be treated with disc sander, wire brush or other appropriate methods.


Oil, dust, and other foreign materials shall be cleaned with thinner, fresh water, wire brush, or compressed air or other proper methods prior to painting.


After the main coat:


After the main coat applied, the damaged area which reaches to the steel surface or the erection joints shall be cleaned according to “The table of surface treatments for damaged areas” and shall be painted as originally specified.


When damage does not reach steel surface, the surface shall be roughened and touched up to specified film thickness.


The table of surface treatments for damaged areas

Location

Prior to the first coat

After the main coat

Flat and Side Bottom

St3

St3

Topside

St3

St3

Exposed main deck

St3

St3

Accommodation,

E/R casing

Exterior

St3

St3

Interior

St2

St2

Engine Room Interior

St2

St2

Fresh water tank

Sa21/2

St3

Cargo hold

St3

St3

Dedicated seawater ballast tank

As PSPC req.

As PSPC req.

Cofferdam, void space

St2

St2

F.O., MGO. ,L.O tank

St2

—

Bilge tank, bilge well

St3

St3

Others

St2

st2


(3)    Surface Cleaning before Over-coating


The surfaces to be cleaned of oil, moisture, dust, and other foreign materials with thinner, fresh water (preferably high pressure), wire brush, or compressed air prior to coating.


Whatever method is used to remove surface contaminant, it should not degrade the surface quality.


2.3.03Painting work


Painting shall be carried out by airless spray mainly. However, hand brush or roller brush may be adopted where it is more suitable than spray.


The sequence of painting for the different part of the hull shall be according to the Builder’s practice.


Mixing and thinning of paint materials, conditions, method of application and interval time between each coat shall be in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendation.


The paint shall not be applied during the period of rain, snow in the open air and also shall not be applied when the weather condition may cause condensation i.e., when the relative humidity is above 85% or the surface temperature of steel is less than 3℃ above the dew point except the case that paint manufacturer has confirmed that a particular paint can be applied at such weather conditions.


In case of the application of the epoxy paint during winter season, the Builder may use the winter type paint recommended by the paint manufacturer.


One stripe coat shall be applied to the cut free edges of structural members, the edges of holes such as slots, scallops, drain holes, air holes, and manual welding beads where the dry film thickness may not always be the specified, before or after the first full coat.


The stripe coating in dedicated sea water ballast tanks shall be applied in accordance with the IMO PSPC.


When the stripe coat is applied after finish of final main coat, the stripe coat shall be same color of final main coat.


The steel structure surfaces including all welded beads to be painted before leak test, in general. However, fillet welding joint and erection seams/butts forming tank boundary to be painted after the joint has been examined either by compressed air test, vacuum test or tank air test as appropriate.


The adhesive tape may be used to protect the fillet joint and erection seams/butts waiting for leak test from contamination by surrounding painting.


The painting of the exposed structural steel surface such as outside of shell, deckhouse,funnel, etc., shall be free from sags and runs.


Measurement of film thickness


Dry film thickness shall be measured after application of final coating.


Measurements of DFT shall be follows.


- Dedicated sea water ballast tanks:

Dry film thickness shall be measured according to the IMO PSPC.


- Fresh water tanks:

90% of measured points shall have the specified DFT, the balance 10% of the points may have DFT of not less than 90% of the specified DFT.


- Other general parts than above:

85% of measured points shall have the specified DFT, the balance 15% of the points may have DFT of not less than 85% of the specified DFT.


No measurement shall be made for plate edges, within 50mm breadth from free edges of any pre-painted steel members, and behind angle bar within 50mm from welding line where the measurement is difficult or impracticable and for erection joint at block stage and cosmetic coating on galvanized fittings, pipes with DN200mm and below.


2.3.04Inspection of Painting


The condition of secondary surface preparation prior to first coating and the total dry film thickness after final coating shall be inspected by three parties (Builder, Paint maker and Buyer).


In case the supervisor fails to be present after due application for inspection the Shipyard shall have the right to continue the painting work.


The cleaning condition and dry film thickness of between coats shall be inspected by two parties (Builder and paint maker). Spot check shall be carried out during Buyer’s patrol inspection randomly.


Buyer have right to spot check the condition of surface preparation prior to first coating of large steel outfitting.

2.3.05Painting Schedule


The painting schedule specified hereunder may have alteration in number of coats and the dry film thickness in accordance with standard specification of the paint maker. However, the total DFT requirement shall be satisfied.

Abbreviation

A/F                :    Anti-fouling paint

A/C                :    Anti-corrosive paint

F/C                :    Finish coat

DFT            :    Dry Film Thickness

TBT            :    Tri Butyl Tin

Maker’s standard


2.4    CATHODIC PROTECTION


ICCP system to be applied on the immersed part of the hull including rudder and propeller.


Mean current density to be 35 mA/m2.


Aluminum alloy anodes with bolting type to be fitted in water ballast tanks and peak tanks.


Life time of anode : Three (3) years

Ballast ratio : 50%

Mean current density : 5 mA/ m2


Sacrificial anodes in sea chest refer to section2.2.18(8).

2.5    MGPS

MGPS shall be provided for anti-fouling for Three (3) years.


The system to be electrolytical type,anode was designed to located on engine room sea chest strainer.


2.6    GALVANIZING


Galvanizing shall be applied for items which are to be galvanized as described throughout the Specification.


The galvanizing shall be done by hot dip method to the thickness of minimum 55 micron except bolts, nuts, screws, etc. which are normally to be electroplated, unless otherwise specified in this Specification.


The damaged parts of galvanized steel surface shall be touch up with one (1) coat of epoxy paint as far as practicable.


In general, the visible outside part of the galvanized outfitting to be painted with one (1) coat of finish paint same as surroundings after installation on board unless otherwise specified in this Specifications, which as far as practicable for cosmetic, the cosmetic coating shall not be guaranteed and D.F.T shall not be measured.


For the invisible parts of the galvanized items’ outside, such as under U-bolts or pipe supports, no more finish coating to be applied after installation.

3    ACCOMMODATION PART

3.1    GENERAL

Accommodation spaces shall be grouped into living spaces, public spaces, control spaces, passage spaces, provisions spaces, sanitary spaces, machinery spaces and sundry spaces as listed below.


These spaces shall be arranged in accommodation as shown in the General Arrangement Plan unless otherwise noted.

3.1.01General Lay-Out


The following spaces shall be arranged in accommodation area as shown on the General Arrangement Plan.

Designation

Wheelhouse with chart space & radio space /Navigation locker /Engine control room in engine room /Fire control room /Battery room /Charge&discharge room /Emergency generator room /CO2 room

Passage space

Sanitary space

Private toilet /Public toilet /Hospital bathroom /Ship’s laundry & drying room /Seafarer’s Officer’s laundry/ & drying room Crew’s laundry /Engine crew changing room /Deck crew changing room

Sundry space

3.1.03Clear Height


The clear height in the living quarters to be about 2100 mm, but sanitary space and catering space may be about 2030 mm from the top of floor covering to the bottom of overhead deck or ceiling. However, the protruding part such as ceiling lamp, ventilating louver and unavoidable corner bracket, etc. to be excluded from the measurement.

3.2    INSULATION, WALL, CEILING, DOORS AND WINDOWS

3.2.01Insulation Material


The insulation material and construction to be in accordance with the relevant Rule and Regulation.


Approximate bulk density of insulation material to be as follows: -


Rock wool    abt.100 kg/m3 for heat and sound insulation with glass cloth finish

    Ceramic wool    abt. 170 kg/m3 for fire insulation


Rock wool and ceramic wool to be secured with copperized steel pin and galvanized washer.

3.2.02Thermo Insulation


The portion of compartment in accommodation space facing weather exposed part to be insulated in accordance with the following table.


Following abbreviation to be used.


RW    :Rock Wool with glass cloth

GS    :Galvanized Steel Sheet (0.6 mm thick) or with Aluminum Foil


Compartment

Overhead in the compartment

Side in the compartment

Public spaces

Control space

Catering spaces

Electric equipment locker

Bonded store

Other miscellaneous stores and lockers which have an entrance to accommodation space

50 RW over plate

25 RW over beam, girder and stiffener + GS

50 RW over plate

25 RW over beam, girder and stiffener + GS


As for the space partially exposed, the insulation to be extended to 300 mm inside beyond the boundary as far as practical.


Note: Beam and girder above 300 mm in depth to be insulated by 300 mm and remaining parts to be left bare.


3.2.03Sound Insulation


The sound insulation to be provided in accordance with the noise level specified in the Section 1.13.01.


Sound insulation (50 mm thick rock wool) to be provided in air conditioning unit room, and engine control room..


For sound insulation room,the overhead and wall shall be insulated with 50 mm inthickness for plate and no insulation of stiffeners.


Engine control room floor to be insulated with 20 mm ceramic wool.


3.2.04Fire Insulation


The fire insulation to be provided according to the Rule and Regulation. The method “IC” of SOLAS to be used.

3.3    PARTITION, CEILING, LINING, DOOR, WINDOW, ETC.

3.3.01 General


Material and installation to be in compliance with the Rule and Regulation.


Bottom of joiner bulkhead to be set in welded steel profile on deck.


Watertight coaming to be made in way of wet space and exterior steel boundary bulkhead.


Wall panel to be jointed and installed in accordance with the maker’s standard.


Other detail of securing and construction of the bottom profile, top profile, skirting, etc. to be in accordance with the Maker’s standard and Builder’s normal practice, unless otherwise required by the Rule and Regulation.


The Builder to provide color samples for the Buyer’s reference of panel finishing.


In general, the main electric cables, vent ducts, piping, shall be concealed behind ceiling and linings.


The piping and branch cable leading to equipment fitted in the room shall not be concealed.


3.3.02Partition Bulkhead


Following space to be enclosed with steel wall:


- Navigation and control space

- Engine control room

- Air conditioning unit room

- Galley

- Pantry

- Dry Provisions space

- Refrigerated Chamber

- Stairway

- Emergency generator room

- CO2 room

- Ship’s laundry & drying room

- Seafarer’s laundry & drying roomElevator machinery room

- Deck store

- Battery room

- Fire control room

- Misc. stores and lockers having an area of more than 4 m2


For other spaces B- Class rock wool board to be used.


The material and thickness of partition to be as follows:


Corridor bulkhead (B-class)    50 mm thick rock wool with 0.6 mm galvanized steel sheets and finished with decorative PVC film on both sides or in accordance with maker’s standard.

Division bulkhead (B–class)    Do.
