Most closed/similar market products may be chosen without notice in advance.


5    HULL PIPING PART

5.1    GENERAL

The general requirements for the piping systems contained herein are particularly applicable to the piping systems outside the engine room, unless otherwise especially stated.


For the detailed and/or the specific requirements of a particular system, the section, which describes the system, shall be referred.


The system shall be designed to meet the requirement of the applicable Rules and Regulations of Classification and regulatory bodies.


Material, dimension and scantling of pipes, valves, flanges, etc. to be generally in accordance with GB or CB /CBM and/or the current maker's standards and Classification requirement,unless otherwise specified. The diameter of connecting flange and the distance between flanges of valve to be according to ISO Standard.

5.2    PIPING MATERIALS AND WORK

5.2.01Pipe

The materials and wall thickness of pipes to be in accordance with section 5.3 “MATERIAL SPECIFICATION FOR PIPING’ and to meet the requirements of the Classification Society.


The specification of pipes forming a part of machinery or equipment supplied by the maker in package to be of the maker’s standard.


In general the material of pipe shall be carbon steel unless otherwise specified.


Seamless steel pipe shall be used where required by the Classification Society.


Copper pipe and aluminum brass pipe shall be of seamless pipe.


Copper or stainless steel pipe shall be used for control pipe of small diameter immersed in seawater continuously for relatively long period of time.


The bore of the pipe shall be decided taken into consideration the maximum flow rate and the corresponding pumping pressure.


The wall thickness of pipe shall according to Classification requirement where applicable.


The dimension of steel pipes shall be in accordance with the Table 5.3.02 “Pipe Thickness Table” and the requirement of the Classification Society.


The materials, joint, coating, etc. shall be in accordance with the Table 5.3.03 “Application of Pipes and Valves”.


The butt-welding joints, sleeve joints, socket joints, bite type / welded unions, threaded unions, all flanges including steel pipe flange for liquid handling should meet requirements of Classification Society for their uses.

5.2.02Valves


In general, valves shall be in according to Chinese Shipbuilding Standard.


In general, the valve size to be of the same nominal bore as that of the pipes connected except automatic control valves or in special cases in accordance with Builder’s practice, maker’s standard and/or Rule requirement.


All shipside valves shall be of flanged type and to be fitted rigidly to the shell plate with a short stub piece of heavy wall thickness in accordance with the Classification Society’s requirement


Shipside valves of butterfly type to be of flanged cast steel or nodular cast iron body, aluminum bronze disc and stainless steel spindle.


Remote controlled valves to be provided in accordance with these Specifications and shall have local manual operation device as required by the Classification Society.

5.2.03General Installation


As far as practicable, the pipelines shall be led directly with a minimum number of bend and the arrangement to avoid forming pocket where drains likely to stay.


Liquid pipelines to be kept away from the switchboard and the electrical appliances. Where the piping is unavoidably led above the electrical appliances, and then welded or sleeve joint shall be provided. In addition suitable sweat proof insulation near the joint shall be provided inside engine room only in order to minimize the possibility of any damage caused by unexpected leakage.


Where the piping pierces girders or any structural element, the compensation, if necessary, to be provided in accordance with the requirement of the Classification Society and the Builder’s standard.


The arrangement of piping to be designed in consideration of convenience in painting hull, cargo handling and traffic as far as practicable.


Piping installed on upper deck to have sufficient clearance from deck for painting and maintenance.


Piping to be designed to release the excessive stress due to thermal expansion/contraction and deflection of the ship’s structure.


Valve nameplates shall be fitted to the valves on handle or other suitable place.


Nameplate shall be provided for air vent heads. Sounding caps engraved with letters in accordance with the Builder's standards.


All nameplates and caution plate shall be in English.


All nameplates and caution plates shall be in accordance with Builder’s practice.

5.2.04Pipe Jointing


Unless otherwise specified, the welding joints of outside sleeve type, butt welding and flange connections generally shall be applied to the pipe connections with valves, fitting, machinery and where necessary for the work according to the Builder’s Practice.


The material of pipe connection shall be of same material or similar to that of pipe, unless otherwise specified.


In general, the flanges shall be of steel slip on welding type for steel piping and the slip on brass brazing type for non-ferrous piping of small diameter.


Where the flange joint of large size stainless or non-ferrous pipes to be applied, the inner ring of composite flange to be of the same material as the pipes connected and the outer flanges to be of hot dip galvanized mild steel.


Chinese standard hexagonal head bolts and nuts of electro-galvanized steel shall be used generally for flange joints.


Where butt-welding joints shall be applied, no backing plate shall be fitted.


Butt welding joint to be applied for straight pipe elbow, reduces, tee and others except otherwise specified.


Sleeve joint shall be used in accordance with Builder’s practice.


Metric threaded and/or welded type unions may be used at dismantling point of small-bore steel pipe or non-ferrous tubes.


Bite type union or welded type unions (for high pressure service, instrument, control and signal) shall be used for copper or stainless steel pipe of small bore.


Brazing type socket joint (for low pressure type) shall be applied for copper, al-brass pipes or stainless steel pipes of 10mm nominal diameter and below and composite flange shall be applied for copper, and al-brass of 15mm nominal diameter and above.


Sliding type coupling joints to be generally used for ballast, bilge, fire main, cable protection lines, etc. where necessary, to compensate the pipes from expansion and contraction.


Packing for sliding type coupling joints to be according to maker’s standard.


Offset expansion bends (Loop) may be applied to the compressed air line, steam line in fuel oil tanks, high pressure hydraulic oil lines and wherever practicable.

5.2.05Bulkhead and Deck Penetration


Where the piping pass through the watertight or oil tight bulkheads and decks, the bulkhead or deck to be sufficiently compensated, where necessary, in accordance with the requirements of the Classification Society, and the connection to be made tight by means of spool piece, direct welding or sleeve reinforced pipe piece according to the Builder’s practice.


The connections through the insulated bulkheads to be of sufficient length to permit access to the flange connections without disturbing the insulation.


For the copper and copper alloy pipes, steel made deck-penetrating pieces to be fitted directly to the bulkhead and/or deck by welding through which those pipes run with proper tightening means.


Domestic cold and hot fresh water copper pipes shall be ran through the bulkhead and deck penetration, but not commonly connected to avoid the effect of discoloration or contamination from welding penetration piece.

5.2.06Branches, Bends and other Fittings


For non-ferrous piping, brazing type tee shall be used for copper pipes of ND 50 mm and below, and for aluminum-brass and copper –nickel pipes of ND 32 mm and below.


Elbow pieces and reducers to be of fabricated steel made by electric arc welding.


Fittings forming a part of pipe to be of the equivalent material as adjoining pipes in general.


As a standard for steel and non-ferrous pipes, the pipe bending to be carried out by means of cold bending machine with bending radius of approximately 3 times the outside pipe diameter, to maximum practicable extent according to shipyard facilities and design convenience.


Where the arrangement does not further allow adoption of required bending radius, miter welding pipe fabricated with radius of about the nominal pipe diameter shall be applied for exhaust pipe and pipes above 600 mm.


Generally the fittings shall be made of rolled fabricated steel and arc welded according to the industrial standard.


Generally the fitting shall be fitted by butt-welding, but flange joint may be applied where those are more favorable.


Hot bending process may be applied in special case, such as adjustment of pipe alignment, etc.


In following cases, standard elbow pieces to be used.


A)    When the capacity of existing bending machine is not enough to bend.

B)    When small bending radius to be necessary to facilitate the piping arrangement.


Loose Fittings

(filters, strainers, traps, rose box, mud box, rose plates, plugs, nozzles, orifice, expansion couplings, separators, air pipe heads, etc.)


The loose fittings to be selected by pipe size, line pressure and pipe line material according to Builder’ standard.

5.2.07Suction Bellmouth


Inverted hopper shape suction bellmouth fabricated of mild steel to be used in general.


The clearance between suction bellmouth and tank bottom to be in accordance with Builder’s standard.


5.2.08Reach Rod


The valve operating reach rods to be of stainless steel in the tanks and solid steel round bar for outside the tanks. Stainless steel pipe and steel pipe also chould be used as reach rod respectively.



The reach rod to be provided with a deck stand, a stuffing box on weather deck penetration, a fork/yoke piece, bevel gear and universal joint according to Chinese standard, where necessary.

5.2.09Gasket and Packing


Non-asbestos sheet gasket packing of anti-sticking surface to be applied in general.


Thickness of gasket packing to be of Maker’s standard.


The material of packing for the valve stem to be of valve maker’s standard.

5.2.10Pipe Supports


The piping to be properly supported and braced as per the Builder’s practice to avoid damage, vibrations and movement due to thermal and/or ship’s deflection. Careful consideration shall be given to expansion pipe fastening supports.


Support for non-ferrous pipe to be inserted with similar non-ferrous sheet metals and/or similar non-ferrous metal hanger so as steel not to be directly contacted with the pipes.


Pipe supports shall be fitted not more than 1.5 meter apart from dresser type expansion coupling.


Fixing supports to be provided for preventing floated pipe from excessive free moving, where required.


For clamping, “U” shape steel round bar bolt clips to be used for steel pipes and flat bar band clips for non-ferrous pipes.


Single nut type U-bolts shall be used for the pipes of ND 80 mm& below except specially mentioned.

Double nuts type U-bolts shall be used for the pipes of ND 100 mm& above and pipes arranged longitudinally on upper deck and in tank.


Pipe supports for main lines in longitudinal direction with nominal diameter of 125 mm and above on upper deck and in pipe duct except electric cable protection pipe, to be fitted with polytetrafluoroethylene(PTFE) sliding pad to allow free sliding pipe movement.


The friction damage protection for non-ferrous or stainless steel pipe shall be provided according to Builder’s practice.


Pipe support and pipe band shall not be welded directly to shell plate.

5.2.11Pipe Protection


The piping works to be protected from mechanical damage, where necessary and the protection to be constructed with steel angles, plates or channels as per Builder’s Practice.

5.2.12Surface Treatment and Cleaning


The surface treatment and coating of the machinery, loose fittings and valves to be carried out in accordance with maker’s standard for the intended purpose, and no special surface treatment to be made exceeding the maker’s standard unless otherwise specified.


The pipe fittings whose function is to join branches of the system (such as tees, Y-pieces, elbow, flanges, unions, sleeve joints, etc.) to be painted same as connected pieces.


The loose fitting other than above pipe fittings supplied by makers (such as expansion coupling, air pipe head, suction bellmouth ,filters, strainers, traps, separator, rose boxes, nozzles, plug, orifice, etc.) to be painted in accordance with the maker’s standard unless otherwise specified.


Galvanizing to be carried out after fabrication of pipes including those final adjusting pipes in principle, but in such case that welding after galvanizing is unavoidable as under-mentioned, the external of the damaged parts to be touched up with one (1) coat of epoxy primer, and internal parts to be touched up with the same paint as far as practicable.


(1)    Welded sleeve joints fabricated on-board

(2)    Flanges of pipes adjusted on-board

(3)    One of flanges of bulkhead/deck penetrating piece

(4)    Anchoring pieces welded on galvanized pipes after adjusting on-board

(5)    Butt weld joint adjusted on-board


The lubricating oil and hydraulic oil pipes to be pickled before installation. After installation on-board, the pipes to be flushed and cleaned prior to being connected to machinery.


Where the acid pickling is necessary for pipes, the acid picking to be done and inside to be treated with oil or equivalent to prevent rust before installation on-board. Ends of pipes after cleaning or installed onboard shall be suitably protected

5.2.13Inspection and Testing


All the tests and inspections of pipe lines to be carried out in accordance with the requirements specified in the specification and/or the Class Rules and the Builder’s standard.


(%5) Visual Test


The dimensions, scantlings, locations, surfaces finishing, welding, fastenings, joints, etc. to be visually inspected where necessary.


(%5) Leakage Test (Flood Test)


The pipes which to be occasionally filled up by gravity or pipes through which liquid flow without pressure during the actual service to be tested by free flow of water to confirm tightness of the pipe lines.


(%5) Pressure Test


The statical hydraulic pressure test to be carried out in accordance with the requirements of the Classification Society and Regulatory Bodies where applicable.


During the pressure test, a blank flange to be provided at the open ends with the valves and/or any other means of closing on the piping fully open.

5.3    MATERIAL SPECIFICATION FOR PIPING

The following material specification to be intended as a guide in the preparation of hull piping schedules for the Vessel and represents minimum requirements or recommendations.

5.3.01Abbreviation in the table


GB

Chinese Standard

CB

Chinese shipbuilding Industrial Standard

Stainless steel pipe

Longitudinally Submerged Arc Welded

SMLS

Seamless

PE

Polyethylene

PE-RT

Heat-resistant polyethylene

Notes:


This table shall be applied generally to the system, and the special requirement by the Class Rules, if necessary shall also be complied with.


(1) Diameter and thickness of hydraulic pipe for valve control to be sized as per maker’s recommendation.

(2) Material of hyd. pipe for deck machinery shall be of high pressure type.

(3) Pipe unless specified as “Galv.” or “No paint” shall be painted in same color as surrounding.

(4) Pipe support shall be painted in same color as surrounding.

(5) Galv. pipe outside on weather part to be applied one coat same as surrounding.

(6) SMLS shall be used for normal diameter less than 400mm, and LASW shall be used for others except special designation. In accommodation, PE-RT Plastic Pipe shall be used for feed water pipeline and PE100 Plastic Pipe shall be used for water drain pipe and soil pipe.

(7) Penetration copper pipe penetrates steel structure through a steel sleeve piece.

5.4    SCHEDULE OF INSULATION OF PIPE

5.4.01Thermal Insulation


The pipe insulation to be applied as follows:


Piping System

Pipe dia. (mm)

Insulation Spec.

Steam supplyor drain line

All

Rock wool (#)

Glass cloth +

Brass wire thread

Hot fresh water line

All

Glass cloth + Brass wire thread

refrigerant pipe line

All

Cross linked polyethylene foam (30t) or equivalent


Note (#): Rock wool cover : 30t, 110 kg/m3

: Rock wool felt: 25t, 80 kg/m3


5.4.02Sweat Protection


Water pipes in accommodation space over the ceiling and over the electrical equipment to be covered with the glass cloth of 0.5 mm thickness.


Drain pipe led from Refrigerated Chamber to be sweat protected in engine room.

5.5    WATER BALLAST SYSTEM

5.5.01Pump Particulars


The following pumps are supplied as per Part 6 - Machinery Specification:

5.5.02Tank Particulars

The following ballast tanks are provided:


Remarks

Fore Peak Tank

No. 1 D.B. &W.B.T. (P&S)

Connect by trunk

Connect by trunk

No. 9 D.B.T. (P&S)

Aft Peak Tank

No.6 Cargo Hold (full ballast)

Heavy ballast only

5.5.03System Principle

The ballast water system shall be provided for loading and discharging ballast water into and out of all the ballast tanks.


No shifting of ballast between ballast tanks shall be considered.


Operation for ballast and de-ballast shall be mainly controlled from the Ballast Control Console including ballast exchange at sea.


All system arrangement shall be in accordance with the Rules and Regulations specified in these Specifications.


Ballast water management plan (BWMP) with Class notation and stamp approval shall be provided.

5.5.04System Description

Ballast pump discharge overboard valve to be provided only at starboard side.


Each double bottom water ballast tank shall be provided with suction bellmouth branched off from one of the two (2) main ballast lines via a remote operated butterfly valve located in the pipe duct.


Two (2) suction wells aft shall be provided for No. 6 floodable holds at port and starboard side of the pipe duct. And two (2) suction wells aft shall each be provided for No.2, 4 and 8 partial floodable holds at port and starboard side of the pipe duct. Portable steel grids to be fitted at the entrance of each of the suction well.


When carrying the dry cargo at the floodable hold, a blank cover to be fitted at each of the end of the hold ballast line to prevent the leakage of ballast water to the hold.


Two (2) main ballast water lines forming a ring main in the pipe duct shall be provided.


The water ballast tanks shall be filled by pumping seawater from sea chest by the ballast pumps provided in the engine room. De-ballast shall be done by ballast pump to overboard in the engine room in normal de-ballast operation.


Aft peak tank shall be ballast by the ballast pump together with other ballast TK ballasting， and deballast by Bilge, Fire/G.S. pumps.


One (1) stripping eductor having capacity of about 200 m3/hr driven by Bilge, Fire and General Service Pumps to be installed in the engine room and connected to the main stripping pipe provided in the pipe duct; another one stripping eductor having capacity of about 300 m3/hr driven by Ballast pump to be installed in the engine room and connected to the ballast main pipe.Separate branch stripping line to be provided for each double bottom ballast tank. A branch suction with stop valve and bellmouth shall be provided for each double bottom water ballast tank. No stripping shall be provided for Aft Peak Tank and Fore peak tank.


Ballast suction valve for Fore Peak Tank on collision bulkhead shall be according to class rules.


Valves for the water ballast system shall be of flangeless type butterfly valve (concentric construction).


Valves at pump discharge side and in pipe duct shall be remotely operated from the ballast control console.


Ballast control console and valve remote control system shall be referred to Section 5.7.

5.6    BILGE SYSTEM

5.6.01Pump Particulars


The following pumps are supplied as per Part 6 - Machinery Specification:


Particular

No.

Type

Capacity (m3/h @ mTH)

Location/ Remark

Bilge stripping educator

1

100 m3/hr x 25mth

Engine Room

Chain locker and Fore void space Bilge Ejector

1

50m3/hr x 25mth

Fore Void Space

5.6.02Compartment Particulars


The following compartments are serviced by bilge system:


Name of Compartment

Served by

Location/Remarks

Cargo Hold

Bilge, Fire & G.S. Pump

Bilge Ejector

In engine room

Chain Locker

Bilge Ejector

In forecastle Driving water from fire main

Steering Engine Room

By gravity

To engine room bilge

Pipe duct

Bilge, Fire & G.S. Pump

Bilge Ejector

Emergency Fire Pump Room

By gravity

To engine room bilge

Forecastle Space

By wall plug

To open upper deck

Forward Void Space

Bilge Ejector

To overboard

Bosun store

Bilge Ejector

To overboard

Echo & Sound. Tank

Bilge Ejector

To overboard

5.6.03System Principle


The bilge system shall be provided according to the Rule requirement. The bilge system for engine room shall be referred to Machinery Specification.


5.6.04System Description


A bilge main line and branch lines to be arranged in the pipe duct and lower stool respectively for drainage of the cargo holds and pipe duct.


Each cargo hold to be provided with two (2) bilge wells arranged at the aft corners.


The pipe duct to have two (2) bilge suctions, one (1) at fore and the other at aft end and to be connected to the bilge main line.


Bilge in forward void space to be discharged by ejector in the fore void space and pumped overboard.


Bilge in the steering gear room, emergency fire pump space and aft rope space to be led to bilge well in the engine room through self-closing valve.


Bilge lines to have a size as required by the Classification Society.


An International Shore Connection with a stop valve for discharging engine room bilge to shore to be provided at each side of the accommodation.


The connections to be blanked off with blind flanges and in compliance with Annex II, Reg.11 of MARPO 73/78.

5.7    BALLAST AND BILGE REMOTE VALVE CONTROL SYSTEM

5.7.01Ballast Control Console


A self-standing ballast control console shall be provided in Ship’s office Room.


Two(2) small touch type mimic panels (LCD type) to be used and arranged on the ballast remote control console. (One for valves remote control system and one for tank level and draft system. The two panels to be served each other.)


Water ingress detection system and alarm for each cargo hold, Fore peak tank and Fore void space with audible / visual alarms shall be provided in the Ship’s office room or Navigation Bridge Deck.

5.7.02Remote Control Valves


Hydraulically operated ballast/bilge valves shall be provided in pipe duct, lower stool, forward void space and engine room (two ballast pump discharge valves) and shall be remotely controlled from the ballast control console, and other bilge /ballast valves in engine room to be manual operated. Valves for Fore Void space bilge shall be operated from the Ship’s office room.


The ballast pump discharge valves shall have proportional (throttling) control.


The actuators of remote valves to be directly coupled to the valves.


Valve open/shut position indication to be provided on the touch panel on the control console and with indicated mark at each local valve.


Remote Control Valvesto be provided according to maker’s standard.In an emergency, such as the failure of hydraulic circuit, the valves to be operated by a portable hand pump.

5.7.03Hydraulic Power Unit

A hydraulic power unit to be provided according to maker’s standard and class’s requirement.in engine room.

5.8    FUEL OIL, MGO & LUBRICATING FILLING SYSTEM

5.8.01Fuel Oil &MGO Filling System

Two (2) heavy fuel oil shore connections and two (2) marine gas oil shore connections of shall be provided in front of the accommodation.


Each shore connection to be blanked off with a butterfly valve and blank flange.


No insulation or steam tracing shall be provided for the filling pipe on weather deck.


The valves associated with the fuel oil filling system shall be manually operated at local side..


The fuel oil sampling tube with valve shall be fitted on heavy fuel oil filling line at each side of the vessel on upper deck. Sampling cock shall be provided for the MGO filling line.


Oil spill coaming to be provided for the filling station.


No fuel filling hose shall be supplied by the Builder.


The Fuel oil filling pipe shall be led to the under deck passage (P&S) directly to the fuel oil bunkering tanks in cargo hold area and to fuel oil storage tanks in engine room. Separate MGO filling pipe shall be led directly to MGO tank in engine room.


Fuel oil discharge line shall be led to deck filling line from the fuel oil transfer pump in the engine room.


MGO discharge line shall be led to deck filling line from the MGO transfer pump in the engine room.

5.8.02Lubricating Oil Filling


One each filling connection of 80 mm in nominal diameter with a blank flange to be provided for the main engine system oil and auxiliary engine system oil separately on each side of the ship.


One filling connection of 80 mm in nominal diameter suitable size to be provided for the main engine cylinder oil on each side of the ship.


5.9    FUEL OIL TANK HEATING SYSTEM


Steel heating coil shall be fitted in the heavy fuel oil bunker tanks.


The heating coil for fuel oil topside wing tanks shall be provided using the following conditions


Seawater temperature5C

Atmopheric air temperature0C

Inside air in cargo hold10C

Air in cofferdam10C

Engine room temperature27C


Heating capacity shall be calculated as following:-


Topside wing tank:from 5C to 35C within 72 hours,Maintain 35C

Engine room:from 30C to 45C within 12 hours,Maintain 45C


Main steam supply pipe to be led from the manifold in the engine room and supplied with 7bar steam.


No heating coil to be provided in the MGO bunker tanks.


Neither insulation nor sparring to be provided between the H.F.O. bunker tanks and cargo hold.

5.10    COMPRESSED AIR SYSTEM


One (1) deck service compressed air line (7 bar) of 40 mm in nominal diameter shall be led on the upper deck with branch and connections on the upper deck and to supply for the followings.


Hose connections for :


Bosun store

Steering gear room (near entrance of Emergency Fire Pump Room)

Air conditioning room

CO2 room

Accommodation deck (P&S) (”A” & NAV. deck only)

Emergency generator room

Air horn


Each one (1) DN15 in nominal diameter hose valve to be provided directly on the Upper Deck branched from the main line at interval of about 30 m.


One (1) hose connection for portable washing machine (water tobey) shall be provided in lower stool of each hold. The portable washing machine to be supplied by Buyer.


A fixed blow out connection to be provided for emergency fire pump sea suction.


Screw service air compressor will be enlarged to about 300m3/h@1.0Mpa, for common use of TIER III SCR urea injection and soot blower. One pressure reducer valve unit will be provided to reduce the pressure to 0.7MPa for ER and Deck service using.

5.11    DECK SERVICE STEAM SYSTEM

Outside the engine room, the steam connection to be required for the following.


Saturated steam at a pressure of 0.7 MPa

Air conditioning unit

Galley

5.12    AIR ESCAPE AND SOUNDING PIPES

5.12.01Air Escape Pipe


Air pipes to be arranged to all spaces as required by the Rules and Regulations.


Air pipes to be located at the highest point in tanks as far as practicable.


Air vent head to be fitted on the top of the air pipe.


Air vent to be provided for the floodable hold at sea going condition and to be fitted on the hatch cover sides.


Air pipe for the oil tanks and fresh water tanks to have a removable stainless steel wire net screen.


Oil coaming to be provided around the air pipe of oil tank in accordance with the USCG requirement.


Height from the deck and the thickness of the air pipes to meet the requirement of the Classification Society.


No air pipe shall be provided for echo sounding/speed log compartment.


Name plate to be fitted to the air pipe head.


Air pipe and closing and its closing devices on exposed deck within 0.25L forward shall meet the requirement of IACS UR S27 and all its revisions that is in force up to the contract signing date.


Air pipes of double bottom ballast tanks shall not be ran through nor direct exposed inside the topside fuel oil tanks.

5.12.02Sounding Pipe


A sounding pipe to be fitted to each engine room tank, bilge well, oil tank, water ballast tank, chain locker, and cofferdam as required by the Classification Society.


Sounding pipe for the heavy fuel oil bunker tanks to be of DN 80mm black steel pipe and the others to be of DN 50mm or DN 40mm galvanized steel pipe.


A strike protector of steel piece to be fitted at the bottom end of each sounding pipe.


Equalizing holes (at least two) to be provided on each sounding pipe at uppermost level in tank.


Thickness of the sounding pipe to meet the requirement of the Classification Society.


Name plate to be fitted on the top of sounding head.


A self-closing leveling cock to be provided for the stern tube cooling water tank instead of sounding pipe at suitable position.


A self content plate level gauge with protection cover to be provided for each fresh water tank instead of sounding pipe. Steps shall be provided for reading the gauge if necessary.


Cargo hold temperature measuring pipe:


The sounding pipes for cargo hold bilge well shall be used for temperature measuring pipe (except NO.9 CARGO HOLD), and one (1) additional temperature measuring pipe of ND 40 mm shall be provided at forward bulkhead in each cargo hold in accordance with the requirement of the Rules and Regulations.


The thickness of sounding pipe and temperature measuring pipes in cargo hold shall be increased to Sch. 160 instead of providing protection from damage.


All portable instruments such as gas detector and PH-meter etc. shall be supplied by the Buyer.


All piping through cargo holds under Sch. 160 shall be suitably protected or fitted in a suitably protected location inside the bulkhead corrugations.

5.13    TANK LEVEL AND DRAFT GAUGE


Water ballast tanks including ForePeak tank, heavy fuel oil tanks and MGO tank shall be provided with electro-pneumatic type remote reading level indication in the ballast control console.


Electro-pneumatic type draft gauge to be provided to read fore, aft and midship (P&S) with remote readout on the ballast control console.

5.13.01 Water Ingress Detectors in Cargo Holds and Dry Spaces


The water ingress detectors should be according to maker’s standard.

5.14    FIRE EXTINGUISHING SYSTEM

5.14.01Fire Fighting Equipment

The fire precaution, extinguishing and fire fighting apparatus to be provided in compliance with the requirement of SOLAS, Classification Society and National Authority.


Fire extinguishing system to be installed to the spaces as follows:

Cargo holdSeawater

Engine roomHigh pressure CO2,

Seawater

Portable fire extinguishers


Fire hazard portions ofFixed water mist system

M/E; diesel generator

engines; incinerator;

boiler fronts &

F.O. purifiers


Cargo deck areaSeawater

Living quartersSeawater,

Portable fire extinguishers

Other required spacesSeawater,

Portable fire extinguishers

Paint storeSeawater

Galley ductLocal CO2

For the fire detecting system, refer to Automatic Control Section.

5.14.02FireWash Deck System


A fire and wash deck line to be served by the Bilge, Fire and General Service Pumps in the engine room and Emergency Fire Pump.


A fire and wash deck main line to be led on upper deck and the branch lines to be led from the main so that the fire protection as well as the deck washing may be done in accordance with the requirement of Rules and Regulations.


One (1) line to be branched from the fire main on upper deck to accommodation.


Branch lines from the main to be led to following:

(1)    Fire hydrants

(2)    Bilge ejector for Fore void space, chain lockers

(3)    Anchor chain washing nozzles

(4)    Cooler for deck machinery, if necessary

A pressure gauge to be fitted on the fire line on Navigation Bridge Deck to check the system pressure.


One (1) International Shore Connection to be provided in accordance with the requirement of the Regulatory Bodies.


For the detail of Bilge, Fire and General Service Pumps, refer to Machinery Specification.

5.14.03Fire Hose and Hydrants


Fire hydrants and hoses with instantaneous quick coupling of GB type to be provided.


Fire hose to be provided with a coupling and a combined jet and water fog nozzle of brass.


Fire hydrants of 50 mm in nominal diameter to be arranged for the exposed decks, living quarter and engine room. The arrangement of fire hydrants and the provisions of hoses and nozzles to be in accordance with the Rules.


Fire hoses to be stowed on the racks or reels and to be arranged for easy removal. Applicators, where required, and adjustable spanner wrench to be secured with clamps or clips.


Hose racks or reels outside of accommodation to be located on the side of deckhouse and to be enclosed in the steel reinforced F.R.P. cabinets.


Cabinets in the forward part of the ship to be located to minimize impact by sea.


Hose racks and hydrants inside the accommodation space to be provided with doors where practicable.


Nine (9) sets of hydrant and branch pipe without fire hose to be provided for hold cleaning.


Hold cleaning machine with hose and quick coupling to be provided by Buyer.

5.14.04Emergency Fire Pump


One (1) emergency fire pump to be installed at the low level in emergency fire pump space as per the General Arrangement Plan.


The pump to draw from the independent sea suction and discharge to the fire and wash deck main line with an isolating valve arranged in an accessible position.


Start/stop of the pump to be in accordance with the Rule requirements.


The pump to have following particulars:


Type:Electric motor driven, self priming, vertical centrifugal type

Capacity:72 m3/hr

Total head:90m

Material:Same as E/R centrifugal pump

5.14.05CO2 Fire Extinguishing System


A total flooding, high pressure CO2 fire extinguishing system consisting of CO2 bottles, piping, control device, discharge nozzles, etc., to be provided for engine room in accordance with requirement of the Regulatory Body concerned.


CO2 bottles to be stowed in a separate room which to be arranged at safe and readily accessible location.


Discharge of CO2 gas to be controlled from deck fire control room and CO2 room, starting CO2 bottle to activate opening of cylinder valve of each CO2 bottle.


CO2 protection for galley duct to be provided as per Rules requirements.


CO2 cylinders for purifier room shall be provided according to class’s requirements.

5.14.06Miscellaneous Fire Fighting Outfits


Portable fire extinguishers and fireman’s outfits, etc. to be provided for the required space in accordance with section 4.11.03 and the requirements of Regulatory Bodies concerned and Classification Society.

5.14.07Safety Plan

Safety plan to be installed in corridor space of accommodation.

-Location of fire pump, hydrants, hose boxes, nozzles etc.

-Location of fire protection controls including emergency stop, shut off, etc. to authorities requirements.

-Location of fire detection, alarm system and portable fire extinguisher.

-Location of fireman’s outfit

-Location of escape route

-Location of other safety devices, emergency stop of fuel /lube oil pump and release valve for CO2 system as required by authorities.

Safety plan (fire control plan + life saving plan) to be colored andprovided on upper deck (P&S) outside accommodation.

5.14.08Fixed Water Mist System (For machinery space)


One (1) set fixed water mist system should be provided in accordance with Rule requirement for local fire extinguishing in Engine Room.


The local fire extinguishing system to be provided for the following machinery:


(1)    Main Engine

(2)    Diesel Generator Engines

(3)    Composite Boiler Burner

(4)    Incinerator

(5)    F.O. Purifiers

5.15    DOMESTIC WATER SERVICE SYSTEM

5.15.01Fresh Water Filling System


One (1) F.W. filling cap to be provided for each F.W. tank.


The filling line from the F.W. Generator in engine room to be fitted to the fresh water tank and wash water tank in engine room double bottom.


5.15.02Fresh Water Service Piping


Refer to Machinery Specification.

5.16    DRAIN AND SANITARY DISCHARGE SYSTEM

5.16.01Weather Deck Scupper


Suitable number of scuppers from decks above the upper deck to be led down to the weather deck below.

5.16.02Gutterway


W.T. sweat gutters to be provided in the living quarters behind lining space according to the Builder’s practiceand to be painted with modified epoxy paint.


The drain from the sweat gutters to be led down to the sweat gutters on the deck below or in case of on sweat gutter, to exposed deck through drain plug made of SUS or brass.

5.16.03Oil Coaming


Steel coaming to be fitted under the air pipe heads and filling connections which are located on the weather deck for the fuel oil tanks, marine gas oil tanks, lub. oil tanks and in way of the international sludge discharge in compliance with the Rule requirement.


Drain plug to be fitted at the lower position of the oil coaming.

5.16.04Indoor Scupper


Scuppers to be fitted in the following compartments where water is used.


Compartment

Size of scupper

Catering space

65 mm

Sanitary space

40 mm

Passage entrance

40 mm

Provision refrigerating chambers

50 mm


5.16.05Waste Water and Soil Discharge System


Waste water (Grey water) from the living quarter other than from the water closets to be suitably collected to the main pipes and to be led to overboard through the screw down storm valves.


Sewage (Black water) from the water closets and urinals, if any, to be collected to the main pipes and to be led to the sewage treatment unit.


A sewage holding tank of 35m3 capacity shall be provided in the engine room for temporary storage of treated discharge of the sewage treatment plant, when its discharge into the harbour or coastal area is prohibited. A sewage shift pump shall be provided to discharge the content of the sewage holding tank to the sea when situation and regulation allows.


6.    MACHINERY PART

6.1    GENERAL

The main propulsion unit shall consist of one (1) heavy fuel oil burning marine diesel engine of the maker's standard product based on the WIN GDdesign, directly connected to and driving a single fixed pitched propeller through a line of shafting. The main engine shall be remotely controlled from the centralized control room in the engine room and from the wheelhouse, and shall be operated at local in emergency. The propeller shall turn clockwise when sailing ahead, seen from aft.


The main engine shall be designed to burn heavy fuel oil with viscosity of up to 380 cSt at 50C under normal sea going, maneuvering, starting and stopping conditions, and to burn MGO under special circumstances when a changeover to MGO may become necessary.


The electric generating system shall consist of three (3) main generators and one (1) emergency generator. The main switchboard shall be suitably arranged in the centralized control room and emergency switchboard shall be arranged in the Emergency Generator Room. The required electric power shall be supplied from one (1) main generator for the Vessel's normal sea going condition except the ballast exchange condition and from two (2) main generators for the cargo handling, in port and harbour in or out conditions.


The steam generating system shall consist of one (1) composite boiler.


Generator engines and the oil-fired side of the boiler shall be designed to burn heavy fuel oil of viscosity 380 cSt at 50C.


Shafting and other auxiliary machinery for propulsion system including the accessories for main engine shall be designed on the basis of Contract max. continuous rating(CMCR) for the main engine.


Centralized controls shall be provided for the propulsion plant, auxiliaries etc.


Exhaust gas emission from the main engine and auxiliary engines shall comply with the IMO NOx Tier II limit as per Rule and with type approval certificate.To comply with IMO NOx Tier III limit, the NOx treatment system for main engine and auxiliary engines shall be applied. In SOX ECA control area, the MGO shall be used.


The provision (blind flanged) for future measuring of the NOx emission shall be fitted at each exhaust gas pipe, and the measuring equipment shall be provided by the Buyer, if necessary.


EIAPP (Engine International Air Pollution Prevention) Certificate, Tier II and III, issued by Class shall be submitted to the Buyer.


All machinery and equipment shall be designed under the following conditions except otherwise stated hereinafter.

Atmospheric air temp.:up to 35 deg C

Atmospheric air pressure1,000 millibar

Relative humidity60%

Machinery space air temp.:up to 45 deg C

Seawater temperature:up to 32 deg C

Related machinery, system and equipment shall also be designed to comply with Classification Society requirement.


Pumps handling oils and oily water shall be capable to maintain the rated capacity and discharge pressure to the viscosity of appropriate liquid according to the following table.

Design condition

Coolers of main engine

M.E. at CMCR

Atmospheric condenser

Note: 1) Cleanliness factor shall be 0.9 for plate cooler and 0.85 for shell and tube cooler as fouling margin.

Major fuel oil and lubricating oil tanks shall be sized according to Rule’s requirement.

6.2    PRINCIPAL PARTICULARS OF MACHINERY

Principal machinery shall be provided in compliance with this Principal Particulars of Machinery. Auxiliary equipment’s/accessories of the principal machinery shall be equipped in accordance with the maker’s standard and the Builder’s practice.

Marine design, IP 23 enclosure, brushless

Remark

Main generator engine to be started and operated on H.F.O. having a viscosity up to 380 cSt at 50ºC.

However, MGO to be used prior to stopping for a prolonged period and major repairs of the fuel system and low load conditions in accordance with the maker’s recommendation.

The diesel engine should comply with limitation of NOx tier II. After using SCR, tier III to be satisfied.

6.3    TEST AND INSPECTION

6.3.01Shop Test and Inspection


The under mentioned running tests shall be executed at the maker’s shop to demonstrate performance of the main diesel engine, diesel generator engines and other auxiliary machinery.


The performance data shall be recorded during these tests and the results shall be furnished to the Buyer as part of Finished Drawing.


Inspections and tests for main engine and diesel generator engines shall be carried out on the basis of the rules of the Class Rules and the maker’s inspection standard.


For such auxiliary machinery as air compressors, pumps, etc. for which certificates of Classification Society are required, the shop tests shall be carried out in the presence of the surveyor of the Classification Society as far as required by Class or otherwise by the makers’ own inspection schedule without attendance of the surveyors.


(1)    Main Diesel Engine

The main components of the Main Diesel Engine shall be inspected after final fabrication as per maker’s standard.


a) Load Test (Marine gas oil shall be used during the shop test):


25% Load CMCR            30 minutes

50% Load CMCR            30 minutes

75% Load CMCR            30 minutes

80% Load CMCR            30 minutes

100% Load CMCR        one (1) hour

110% Load CMCR    Demonstration only accordance with maker’s standard    30 minutes


The brake horse power shall be measured by the maker’s hydraulic type dynamometer.


b) Governor test

c) Starting and reversing test at no load

d) Emergency trip test

e) Astern running test at no load

f)Fuel oil consumption measurement for guaranteed F.O. consumption.

g)Crankshaft deflection measurement before and after the shop trial

h) Engine side maneuvering stand at no load

i)Turning gear interlock.


Note: The above tests shall be done according to Rule’s requirement and M/E maker’s recommendation.


(2)    Diesel Generator Engine

a) Load Test (Marine gas oil shall be used during the shop test)


25% Load of Generator........30 minutes

50% Load of Generator........30 minutes

75% Load of Generator........30 minutes

100% Load of Generator........60 minutes

10% overload of Generator........20 minutes


b) Starting test at no load

c) Governor test

d) Emergency trip test

e) Voltage and speed regulation test

f) Parallel running test

g) Fuel oil consumption measurement (at each load test)


These tests shall be carried out with the generator coupled to the engine.


Fuel oil used at shop trial shall be marine gas oil as per maker’s standard


(3)Composite boiler


Hydraulic pressure test in assembled condition


(4)    Propeller


Survey and balance test after completion


Shop test shall be carried out in accordance with each maker’s standard and required by the Regulatory Bodies.

6.3.02Open Up Inspection at Shop after Trial


(1)    Main Engine


Open inspection to be carried out as below after shop test.


No.

Overhaul item

Q’ty

Inspection

1

Crankshaft

1 bearing

Appearance inspection without lifting up from bedplate (main and crank pin bearing only to be dismantled)

2

Main bearing

1 bearing

Appearance inspection (upper and lower shells to be dismantled from bedplate

3

Cylinder liner

1 cyl.

Appearance inspection of inner surface

4

Cylinder cover

1 cyl.

Appearance inspection of combustion surface (to be dismantled from engine) with exhaust valve dismantled from the cylinder cover

5

Crosshead bearing, crank pin bearing, crosshead pin & guide shoe

1 cyl.

Appearance inspection of bearing surface

6

Piston complete

1 cyl.

Appearance inspection, (to be dismantled from engine)






(2)    Diesel generator engine


Open inspection shall be carried out in accordance with the maker’s standard overhaul check.

6.3.03On Board Test


After the main diesel engine, diesel generator engines, auxiliary machinery and electrical equipment are installed onboard and relevant piping and wiring are fitted, these machines shall be operated and examined to check whether their functions are satisfactory.

6.4    MAIN ENGINE

6.4.01General


The design of the main engine shall be based on conditions mentioned in Section 6.1.


The construction, materials and fittings for the engine to be in accordance with the engine maker’s standard in compliance with the requirement of the Classification Society.


Automatic and remote control systems for the propulsion plant shall be in accordance with maker’s standard. The direction of rotation of crankshaft to be clockwise viewed from aft when running ahead.


Pipes, valves, gauges, etc. fitted on the engine by the engine maker shall be in accordance with the engine maker’s standard.


All main parts for M/E subject to normal wear during operation shall be interchangeable with those of WIN GD Deisel.


6.4.03Cooling system


Cooling system of main engine to be as follows:


Lubrication oil cooling:Freshwater

Scavenge aircooling: Freshwater

Cylinder jacket cooling:Fresh water

Piston cooling:Lubricating oil

Turbocharger:            Maker’s standard


6.4.04Accessories and Fittings


The following accessories and fittings shall be included in the main diesel engine.


-    Exhaust Gas Turbocharger


Type        high efficiency type

Bearing        As per maker’s standard

Lubrication    As per maker’s standard

Accessories    According to maker’s standard.


-    Air cooler     Single stage      F.W. cooled

Cleaning : Chemical water cleaning system shall be arrangedin accordance with the maker’s recommendation


-    Auxiliary Blowers    Two(2) auxiliary blowers with electric motor and starter.

-    Turning Gear

-    Thrust bearing

-    Flywheel

-Crank case oil mist detector.

-Fuel oil sliding type valve to be applied

-Local controlpanel LCP

-Fire extinguishing steam pipe for scavenge air space


Others to be in accordance with the maker’s standard.

6.4.05NOx Tier III solution


A high pressure Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system to be install on main engine, to reduced NOx level in compliance with the NOx Tier III requirements.


The NOx reduction is obtained by a catalytic process in an SCR reactor installed in the exhaust gas line after the combustion process. In the SCR reactor, the NOx is reduced catalytically to nitrogen and water by adding urea as a reducing agent.


The SCR consists of two major components: the combined vaporizer/mixer unit and the SCR reactor. In the vaporizer, the catalytic process is prepared by injecting the reducing agent which will vaporize and mix with the exhaust gas. The prepared gas is led to the SCR reactor where the NOx reduction takes place. A soot blowing system is to be installed for SCR reactor.


The SCR is to be placed before the turbocharger. Bypass pipes and isolate valves to be provided that the SCR system can be isolated if the vessel sails at none NECA.


A storage tank about 25 m3 of urea solution to be provided in engine room. The tank shall be steel with special coating. The volume of the storage tank calculated base on the following date:


Description

Value

Fuel oil sulphur content

Max. 0.1%

Concentration of urea solution

Abt. 40%

Bunker period of urea solution

6 times/year

ECA sailing time

600 hrs/year

Main

Engine

25% SMCR

30%

50% SMCR

30%

75% SMCR

30%

100% SMCR

10%

Main

Generator

MCR

2 x 100%


The piping system of urea to be SUS 316L.


The control and operation of SCR system shall be done at local and ECR according to the manufacturer's standard.

6.4.06Installation


The bedplate of main engine shall be fastened to its seating on the tanktop by hydraulic holding down bolts. Resin chocks shall be fitted between bedplate and seating on each side for leveling the engine foundation. Hydraulic top bracing arrangement shall be provided.


The main engine shall be installed in accordance with the engine maker’s recommendation in compliance with the requirement of the Classification Society.

6.5    SHAFTING

6.5.01General


The propeller and shafting shall be designed and manufactured in accordance with the requirement of the Classification Society and the Regulatory Bodies as far as they are concerned.


The shaft diameter, the propeller diameter, the number of blades and other details shall be determined and designed in consideration of the main engine’s torsional vibration as well as hull vibration.


Considerations shall be given to the engine’s rotating masses including shafting, main engine and propeller so as to be free as far as possible from all major stresses due to torsional vibration in the normal operating and maneuvering range. In case such critical speed is unavoidable then such critical speed shall be marked on the revolution indicator and approved by the Classification Society.

6.5.02Intermediate Shaft


The diameter of the intermediate shaft shall be designed based on the requirements of the Classification Society and other design factors, and shall be increased by 5mm in way of the shaft bearing.


The shaft shall be of forged steel and shall be provided with integral flanges at both ends.


Shaft coupling flanges shall be fitted with reamer bolts.


A shaft-grounding device shall be provided on the intermediate shaft to electrically connect the shafting to the hull for the reduction of voltage difference between them.


A shaft/hull milli-voltmeter shall be furnished to check that the shafting is properly grounded.


The shaft-grounding device shall be of capacity to keep the potential voltage below 50 mv during revolving.

6.5.03Propeller Shaft


The propeller shaft shall be designed in accordance with the requirements of the Classification Society and the diameter shall be increased by not less than 5mm above Rule requirement.


The shaft shall be of forged steel with an integral flange at the fore end and a cone part at the aft end.


The cone part of the propeller shaft shall be machined to a taper of 1 to 20 for fitting the keyless propeller and hydraulic nut. The cone surface shall be properly faced up between propeller and propeller shaft.


The flange of propeller shaft shall be marked with reference line for propeller blade position.


The propeller shaft shall be terminated in a left hand thread consistent with a hydraulic nut.


The propeller shaft shall be withdrawn inboard after removing the intermediate shaft and it’s removal from the Vessel shall be carried out via a temporary opening cut in the shell plating. Such opening area shall be marked and painted with black and yellow strips on the inside of the shell plate.


No spare propeller shaft shall be provided.

6.5.04Intermediate Shaft Bearing


A self-lubrication steady bearing shall be furnished to support the intermediate shaft. L.T. Cooling Fresh Water from L.T. F.W.Cooling Pump shall be led to the bearing for cooling.


The steady bearing shall consist of two sections, a lower and upper half of cast iron construction with white metal lining.



6.5.05Coupling Bolt and Nut


Hyd. Couple bolts and nuts shall be used for flange coupling between the main engine/intermediate shaft and the intermediate shaft/propeller shaft.


Bolts connecting intermediate shaft to main engine may be as per maker's standard


6.5.06Stern Tube and Bush Bearing


The stern tube shall be of welded steel plate construction, which is welded to the ship’s stern frame boss forming a part of hull structure.


The fore and aft stern tube bush shall be of cast iron with a lining of white metal having a length consistent with a suitable bearing load in accordance with the Classification requirement.


6.5.07Stern Tube Seals


The seals shall be of lip type incorporating synthetic rubber Viton sealing rings.


The stern tube seals shall be of air seal type.


The aft seal shall be designed to allow replacement of the sealing rings without disconnecting the shafting or propeller.


The forward & aft seal casing materials shall be according to maker’s standard.


The forward seal liner and the aft seal liner shall be according to maker’s standard.


The sealing ring materials shall beaccording to maker’s standard.


6.6    PROPELLER

The direction of rotation shall be clockwise viewed from the aft when running ahead.


The propeller shall be designed in conjunction with analysis of propulsion efficiency, cavitation and the extent of vibration to the hull’s superstructure and machinery.


The material of propeller shall be nickel-aluminum-bronze.


The keyless propeller shall be attached to the cone part of the propeller shaft which has the taper of about 1/20 and shall be secured by the hydraulic nut.


A simple hand operated hydraulic oil injector shall be furnished.


Oil grooves shall be provided on the inner surface of the taper bore of the propeller for its fitting and removal.


The propeller cap of manganese bronze or nickel aluminum bronzeshall be bolted to the hub, and its interior to be filled with suitable rust preventive materials.


After finishing according to ISO class I, the propeller to be statically tested according to the maker’s standard method.


The propeller pitch shall be designed to absorb CSR power at CSR rpm with at least 5% margin in rpm at the design draft, in calm sea and with clean hull bottom condition.


No spare propeller shall be provided.

6.7    STEAM GENERATING PLANT

6.7.01General


One (1) Composite Boiler shall be provided in the engine room to generate steam for heating purpose:


Steam capacity:abt.800 Kg/h for exh. gas section(according to maker’s calculation)

abt. 2,500 Kg/h for oil fired section


Working pressure:0.7 MPa

Feed water temperature:80 deg.C.


The steam output of exh. gas section shall be delivered at CSR of main engine under ISO reference condition.


The system shall be designed for simultaneous heating of the following:


One of HFO bunker tanks ( heating & keeping)

One of HFO bunker tanks (keeping)

Engine room heaters

Domestic heating


In case of steam deficiency produced by exh.gas section, the oil fired section of the boiler shall be used in addition.


6.7.02Construction and material


The construction, material, fittings, gauges, valves, etc. shall be provided as per boiler maker’s standard in compliance with the requirement of the Classification Society.


6.7.03Accessories and Fittings


The boiler shall be fitted with accessories according to maker’s standard and the requirement of the Classification Society.


The composite boiler shall be built and constructed in accordance with the Class Rules and maker’s standard.


One (1) oil burner shall be provided for heavy fuel oil and marine gas oil burning.


The steam pressure remote gauge and water level remote gauge shall be provided in ECR console.


Alarm shall be provided as per boiler maker’srecommendation.


6.7.04Installation


The composite boiler shall be installed in engine room with proper reinforcement of the deck structure. Anti-rolling stays shall be fitted in accordance with boiler maker’s recommendation. (if necessary)


No exhaust by-pass shall be provided.




6.8    ELECTRIC POWER PLANT

6.8.01Main Diesel Generator Engine


(1)    General


The diesel generator engine shall be of four stroke, trunk piston type equipped with turbocharger.


The diesel generator engines shall be started/stopped and operated with heavy fuel oil having a viscosity up to 380 cSt at 50C.


However, marine gas oil shall be used in emergency situations or long-term low load conditions in accordance with the maker’s recommendation.


Fuel oil change-over from H.F.O. to M.G.O. and vice versa shall be carried out manually at local.


Compressed air shall be used for starting of the diesel generator engine.


The cylinder jackets, cylinder covers, the air cooler and lubricating oil cooler shall be cooled by fresh water.


The governor to control the diesel engine speed shall meet the requirements of the Classification Society and authority.


(2)    Construction and Materials


The construction and materials of the generator engine shall be in accordance with the engine maker’s standards in compliance with the requirements of the Classification Society.


Pipes, valves, gauges etc., fitted on the engine by the engine maker shall be in accordance with the engine maker’s standard.


(3)    Accessories and Fittings (for each diesel generator engine)


FWcooling pumpThe maker’s standard1 set

(Engine driven)

Lubricating oil pumpThe maker’s standard1 set

(engine driven)

TurbochargerThe maker’s standard1 set

Silencer1 set

Air cooler1 set

Lubricating oil coolerThe maker’s standard1 set

GovernorThe maker’s standard1 set

G/E L.O. priming pump1 set

F.W. pre-heated unit1 set/ship


Other accessories shall be provided by maker according to maker’s standard and the requirement of the Classification Society.


(4)    Installation


Generator engines shall be directly coupled with the alternator and mounted on a common bed.


The generator with alternator shall be installed on board according to maker’s recommendation (resin chock liner shall be considered).


(5)    SCR system


The following apparatus shall be onboard (each vessel):

3 SCR units for main diesel generator engines

1 – urea supply unit

1 – soot blower

6.8.02Emergency Diesel Generator Engine


(1) General


The emergency diesel generator engine shall be of radiator cooled type.


The engine shall be started by the electric storage battery primarily and the secondary starting method according to the maker’s standard.


MGO (grade DMA or DMX of ISO-8217) shall be used for the emergency generator engine.


(2) Construction and materials


The construction, material, accessories and fittings shall be provided in accordance with the engine maker’s standard in compliance with the requirements of the Classification Society.


(3) Installation


The emergency generator engine shall be coupled with the alternator and mounted on a common bed plate.


The emergency generator set shall be installed in the emergency generator room outside the engine room and mounted by means of resilient supports.


Emergency G/E M.G.O. tank outlet shut off valve shall be operated outside the emergency generator room.

6.9    AIR COMPRESSORS & AIR RESERVIORS

6.9.01Main Air Compressor

(1) General


The total capacity of the main air compressor shall be able to charge the main air reservoirs from atmospheric pressure to pressure required for twelve (12) starts of main engine within one (1) hour.


Main air compressors shall be fresh water cooled type with self-contained lubricating system and shall be driven by an electric motor.


Each compressor shall be stopped and started according to high and low pressure of air reservoir automatically or manually.


(2) Construction and material


Construction and materials shall be in accordance with the Manufacturer’s standard in compliance with the requirement of the Classification Society.


(3)    Accessories shall be provided according to maker’s standard and the requirement of the Classification Society.

6.9.02 Auxiliary Air Compressor

(1) General


The capacity of auxiliary air compressor shall be able to charge the auxiliary air reservoir from atmospheric pressure to pressure required for one (1) start of main generator engine within fifteen (15) minutes.


The auxiliary air compressor shall be air cooling type, and shall be of electric driven by motor mounted on common bedplate.


(2) Construction, material and Accessory


Construction, material and accessories shall be in accordance with the maker’s standard.

6.9.03Main air Reservoir

(1)     General


The main air reservoir shall be of the cylindrical welded steel construction.


The total capacity of air reservoirs shall be sufficient to start the main engine more than twelve (12) times without recharging in accordance with the requirements of the classification Society.


(2)     Construction, materials and accessories


Construction, materials and accessories shall be in accordance with the maker’s standard in compliance with the requirement of the Classification Society.

6.9.04Auxiliary Air Reservoir

(1)     General


Volume of the auxiliary air reservoir shall have sufficient capacity to start one (1) main generator engine more than three (3) times without recharging.


(2)     Construction, materials and accessories


Construction, materials and accessories shall be in accordance with the maker’s standard and the requirement of the Classification Society.

6.9.05Control Air Reservoir

(1)     General


Volume of the control air reservoir shall have sufficient capacity to supply the normal control air requirement


(2)     Construction, materials and accessories


Construction, materials and accessories shall be in accordance with the maker’s standard and the requirement of the Classification Society.

6.10    PUMP

6.10.01General


The electric motor for each pump shall have sufficient power for the entire discharge range of the pump.


The pumps, which are necessary for priming, shall have an attached self-priming device.


Base of oil pumps shall be equipped with oil tray or coaming.


Horizontal type pump and motor shall be mounted on a common bedplate.


Packing, accessories and spares etc. shall be in accordance with the maker’s standard unless otherwise specified.


Pump shall be fitted with suction and discharge pressure gauges with a root cock.


Sufficient space for access and maintenance and repair shall be provided as far as possible.


The construction materials and design for other pumps, which are not mentioned in this Specification shall be in accordance with the maker’s standard.

6.10.02Centrifugal pump


In the case of a vertical pump having a bottom bearing, the bearing shall be immersed in the handling liquid.


Centrifugal pump shall be fitted with mechanical seal except deepwell type centrifugal pump, boiler water circulating pump and vacuum pump which are provided with the seal according to the maker’s standard.


Pump casings, except for small size pumps and specially constructed type pumps, shall be so constructed that the rotating members may be overhauled for inspection or replacement without disconnecting the attached pipe.


However, the electric motor may be taken off according to the maker’s standard.


Materials:


Continuous running Seawater pump (at normal sea going condition);


Casing            Cast bronze

Impeller    Stainless steel or Maker’s standard

Shaft            Stainless steel


Other Seawater pump:


Casing            Cast bronze

Impeller            Bronze or phosphor bronze

Shaft            Stainless steel


Fresh Water pump:


Casing            Cast ironor Maker's standard

Impeller            Bronze or phosphor bronze

Shaft            Stainless steel


Main L.O. pump:


Casing            Cast iron

Impeller            Bronze or phosphor bronze

Shaft            Carbon steel or Cr-Mo steel

6.10.03Rotary pump


The bearing shall be internally placed in the pump casing and to be lubricated according to the maker’s standard.


The pumps shall be provided with built-in safety valve or by-pass valve to protect the pump and electric motor against the excessive pressure.


Materials :


Gear pump:


Casing            Cast iron

Gear & shaft        Carbon steel

Sealing            Mechanical seal


Screw pump


Casing            Cast iron

Power rotor        Carbon steel

Idle rotor        Carbon steel or cast iron

Sealing            Mechanical seal


Mono pump (1-rotor type)


Casing            Cast iron or mild steel

Power rotor & shaft    Stainless steel

Plunger stator        Synthetic rubber

Sealing             Gland packing


Piston pump


Casing            Cast iron

Piston rod        Stainless steel

Sealing            Gland packing

6.11    OIL PURIFIER

6.11.01General


Each purifier shall be provided with an independent and thermostatically controlled steam heater.

6.11.02Heavy Fuel Oil Purifier

(1) General

Two (2) sets of H.F.O. purifier shall be provided in the purifier room.


Each purifier shall have the capacity to purify total F.O. consumption of main engine and one (1) main generator engine at their rated output.


One (1) for working and the other for stand-by.


One (1) of them to be arranged for purifying M.G.O.


One (1) automatic control board with timer and abnormal alarm shall be arranged for each purifier near the purifiers.


(2) Construction, materials and accessories

Construction, materials and accessories shall be in accordance with the maker’s standard and the requirement of the Classification Society.

6.11.03Lub. Oil Purifier

(1)     General

Two (2) sets of L.O. purifier shall be provided in the purifier room.


L.O. purifier shall be provided for purifying lube oil of main engine and main generator engines.


(2)     Construction, materials and accessories

Construction, materials and accessories shall be in accordance with the maker’s standard and the requirement of the Classification Society.

6.12    ENGINE ROOM VENTILATION FAN

6.12.01General


The fans shall be of vertical and axial flow type.


The total supply capacity of ventilation fans shall be determined based on ISO 8861.


Two(2) of the four ventilation fans shall be of reversible type.


A separate extraction fan shall be furnished for the purifier room.

2.%2.%3 Construction and Material


The fan impeller and driving motor shall be incorporated in the fan casing.


The fan casing shall be of split type with hinges. Interior of fan casing to be coated with epoxy paint and the hinge pin shall be of SUS.


Material of fan shall be as follows:


Casing        :    Steel

Impeller        :    Aluminum alloy


“Open” and “Shut” indicator of brass plate to be provided for fan dampers.

6.13    HEAT EXCHANGER

6.13.01Plate Type Cooler


(1) General


The plate cooler shall be designed with the fouling margin of 10%.


(2) Construction


The heat exchanging surface to consist of number of corrugated plates clamped together in a frame and sealed at edges by rubber gaskets.


Other construction shall be in accordance with maker’s standard.


(3)    Materials:


Frame            Mild steel

    Plate            Titanium (for sea water cooling)

                Stainless steel alloy (for fresh water)

Gasket            Nitrile Rubber


(4)    Accessories


Accessories shall be provided according to the maker’s standard and the requirement of the Classification Society.

6.13.02Shell and Tube Type Cooler and Condenser


(1) General


Capacity of the coolers and the auxiliary condenser shall be based on the seawater temperature of 32 deg.C. and fresh water temperature of 36 deg.C with with the fouling margin of 15%.


(2) Construction


The tubes shall be expanded into the tube plates at both ends of the tubes.


The cooling fluid shall pass through the tubes and the cooled fluid shall flow outside of the tubes.


Other construction shall be in accordance with maker’s standard


(3)    Materials :


Tube            Aluminum brass

Tube plate        Naval brass

Shell            Steel plate or steel pipe

Water box and cover    Cast iron or steel plate


(4)    Accessories:


Accessories shall be provided according to the maker’s standard and the requirement of the Classification Society.

6.13.03M/E Jacket Cooling F.W. Heater


The M/E jacket cooling F.W. heater shall be in accordance with maker’s standard.

6.13.05Fresh Water Generator


(1) General


The jacket cooling water from the main engine shall be used as heating medium during normal seagoing voyage.


The F.W. generator shall be able to produce the rated capacity of F.W. when main engine is running at CSR output.



(2) Construction materials and accessories


The construction, materials and accessories shall be in accordance with the maker’s standard.


6.14    AUXILIARY MACHINERY

6.14.01Incinerator


The incinerator shall be installed in compliance with IMO requirement.


The incinerator shall be a steel frame enclosing a combustion chamber and insulated on the outside.


Sludge oil and solid waste can be burnt simultaneously.


The solid waste cannot be loaded while in operation.


The burner system as per maker’s standard shall be used for the incinerator.

6.14.02Hydrophore Unit


(1) General


The fresh water hydrophoreunit shall be provided to supply fresh water for the domestic, sanitary and engine room service.


The unit shall consist of a hydro-pneumatic pressure tank and electric motor driven centrifugal supply pumps.


The supply pumps shall start and stop automatically at the preset pressure.


(2)    Materials:


Tank        Steel

Pump        Refer to section on centrifugal pump

Other        The maker’s standard


(3)    Accessories:


Accessories shall be provided according to the maker’s standard and the requirement of the Classification Society.


6.14.03Sterilizer/Mineralizer


An ultraviolet type of sterilizer and a dolomite or equivalent type of mineralizer shall be provided downstream of the hydrophore unit in order to produce potable water supplying to drinking water fountain, galley and pantries.

6.14.04Calorifier


(1) General


A calorifier heated by steam and electricity (for emergency use) shall be provided to supply hot water to the accommodation.


(2)    Materials;


Body    Stainless steel

Steam coil    Copper or stainless steel

Electric heater    Stainless steel

6.14.05Oily Bilge Separator


The oily bilge separator shall be of approved type by the National Authorities under IMO resolution MEPC. 107 (49).


The oil content of treated water shall be less than 15 ppm and a high oil content bilge alarm shall be provided.

6.14.06Marine Growth Preventing System


A marine growth preventing system shall be provided for the sea chest strainerto prevent the marine organism from adhering to the interior of cooling seawater system.

6.15    PIPE AND FITTINGS

6.15.01General


The pipe system in the engine room shall be designed to absorb the stresses caused by thermal expansion and deflection of the ship’s structure.


The steam and oil piping shall be arranged sufficiently far away from electrical instruments, in principle.


Pipe fittings shall be so arranged that leaking may not disturb the electrical gear such as switchgear, etc, if unavoidable, proper protection shall be provided.


The piping shall be suitably supported so as not to be damaged by vibration.


Neoprene, lead or brass plate shall be inserted in pipe straps for non-ferrous pipes in accordance with the Builder’s standard practice.


Air pockets in the piping shall be eliminated wherever possible. If unavoidable, air vents or screwed drain plugs shall be fitted.


The vents and drain lines shall be stepped-sloped effectively wherever possible. If unavoidable, a plug shall be fitted for drainage.


The pumps, heat exchangers and other equipment shall be capable of overhauling with removal of the connected pipes. Also minimum clearance shall be left around all valves, fittings and strainers to allow overhauling/cleaning without being removed from piping.


Generally, slip-on flange joints shall be used for connections of steel pipes. However, the pipes of the normal diameter of 10 mm and below shall be connected by union or sleeve joints for overhaul and inspection of valves or machinery.


The pipes, which are specified as “galvanized” shall be galvanized after fabrication of the pipe. When the galvanized pipe is subjected to hot work or welding for re-adjustment purpose, the pipe shall be re-galvanized as far as possible. If unavoidable partial welding is required after galvanizing, one coat epoxy paint shall be used for repair of the welding damage.


Piping shall be led as direct as practicable with a minimum number of bends and joints.

Pipe bending shall be carried out by cold bending machine in general.


Where the arrangement does not allow adoption of required bending radius, miter welding pipe fabricated with radius of about the nominal pipe diameter shall be applied for exhaust pipe and pipes above 600 mm.


Where pipes pass through watertight decks or bulkheads, penetration pieces shall be used.


The pipes shall be hydrostatically tested in accordance with the requirements of the Classification Society.


Emergency shut-off valves which are fitted on the oil tank suction in compliance with the requirements of the Classification Society shall be of such a design that can be shut quickly by means of pneumatic device controlled from outside engine room.


Asbestos shall not be used as the material of insulation, gasket, etc.


Rubber gasket shall not be used for flanges on steam piping.


Material and pipe work of piping attached to the main and auxiliary machinery’s shall be in accordance with the maker’s standard.


For connecting pipes of different diameters, commercial reducing piece shall be applied.


Piping in engine room and in accommodation shall be marked with colour tape for easy recognition.


One (1) relief valve and one (1) pressure gauge shall be provided at each air pressure reducing valve outlet side.


Three (3) way type control valves shall be provided with manual operating device and no bypass line.


Two (2) way type control valve without manual control device shall be provided with by-pass line.


Drain trap for continuous service shall be provided with by-pass line.

6.15.02Piping Materials And Application


Materials for pipes and valves on each system shall be as stated below in following table:


For pipe thickness and abbreviation used in the following table, refer to hull piping.
