600mm and below

SMLS or LSAW

Ship side valve

50mm and above

#Nodular cast iron, cast steel/Stainless steel or bronze

10




16


40mm and below



Bronze

Air vent & sounding for independent tank

400mm and above

LSAW

SCH.40

Steel flanged or sleeve joint

5

below 400mm

SMLS

SCH.40

Air vent & sounding for hull-structured tank

400mm and above

LSAW

SCH. 40 for all

SCH 80 for weather deck

Steel flanged or sleeve joint

5

below 400mm

SMLS

SCH. 40 for all

SCH 80 for weather deck


Notes;


1. Fittings of 10mm and below in nominal diameter shall be, in general, of cast bronze.

2. Joints of 10mm and below in nominal diameter shall be, in general, of bite compression type fitting using stainless steel materials.

3. Flangeless connection of sleeve joint shall be used whenever practical on all steam exhaust and drain system.

4. Sleeve joint may be used for low-pressure lines (up to 10 kg/cm2) and pipe connections at hull block joint parts.

5. The valves marked with “#” shall be, in general, of butterfly type valve having the material as specified in Table 2. However, other valve types may be used, too.

6. Sacrifice flangeshall be fitted at the S.W. handling pump suction sides, and S.W. inlet & outlets of titanium plate type coolers.

7. Double nuts type U-bolts shall be used for the pipes of ND 100mm& above in engine room.Single nut type U-bolt shall be used for the pipes of ND 80mm&below in engine room except specially mentioned and/or according to maker’s standard.

8. Material of valve body/disc & seat for ship side valve of 65mm and above shall be according to Rule.

9.    Disc and seats of non-return valve installed on discharge side of seawater pumps which start automatically shall be of stainless steel.

10.    Sleeve joints shall not be used for pressurized steam pipes and steam drain except heating coils in tanks.

11. SMLS shall be used for normal diameter less than 400mm, and LASW shall be used for others except special designation.


Butterfly valve


Use

Size

Material

Body & Seat

Joint

F.W & S.W. cooling lines, L.O. Lines Ballast Lines

(10 kg/cm2G and below)

80mm and over

Cast iron body lined with synthetic rubber seat

Flangeless

Sea suction & overboard discharge (attached on hull)

80mm and over

Cast steel or nodular cast iron body lined with synthetic rubber seat

Flanged


Note :


1. Where butterfly valves are fitted directly at inlet and outlet of tubular type heat exchangers, they shall be of flange joint type or equivalent.

2. Minor modifications may be applied to Table 2 according to the maker’s standards.

3. The material of following valves and fittings shall be used in accordance with the maker’s standard.


Temperature control valve

Pressure control valve

Pressure reducing valve

Safety valve

Steam trap with strainer

6.16    FUEL OIL SYSTEM

6.16.01General


Fuel oil system shall be installed for main engine, auxiliary engines, composite boiler, incinerator and emergency generator engine as per maker’s recommendation and descriptions in the sections below.

6.16.02Fuel Oil Filling, Transfer System, Overflow and Drain system


Separate bunker lines for heavy fuel oil and marine gas oil shall be arranged on port and starboard side of upper deck in front of accommodation.


The bunker lines shall be fitted with butterflyvalves and a flange connection with a blank flange.


LS H.F.O. and M.G.O. shall be filled by gravity to LS H.F.O. bunker tanks and M.G.O. bunker tank respectively.


MGO shall be used in SOx controlled area.


LS H.F.O transfer pump shall take suction from LS H.F.O bunker tanks and discharge to the deck, LS H.F.O. settling tanks and other LS H.F.O. bunker tanks. A F.O. Drain tank shift pump shall take suction from the F.O. Drain tank and discharge to the LS H.F.O. Settling tanks.


Fuel oil filling line on deck shall keep sufficient clearance from deck and accommodation front wall for maintenance and repair purposes.


M.G.O.transfer pump shall take suction from M.G.O. storage tank and discharge to the deck, M.G.O. settling tank and Incinerator fuel tank.


M.G.O. transfer pump shall be intended as stand-by for LS H.F.O. transfer pump and vise versa.


The stand-by connection pipe at transfer pumps suction and discharge side shall be normally closed by a spectacle flange with stop valve.


LS H.F.O. and M.G.O. overflow pipe of settling tanks shall be led to the F.O. overflow tank.


Overflow pipe of service tank shall be arranged internally from the lower part of the service tank to the top of the settling tank.


LS H.F.O.,M.G.O. settling tanks and service tanks shall be equipped with self-closing drain valve and hopper for drain.


Oil tight coaming shall be arranged below the valves on the tanks.


Drain from coaming shall be led to the F.O. drain tank.


Fuel oil drain from all oil coamings and base plates for fuel oil transfer and heating equipment shall be led to the F.O. drain tank.


Sludge pump shall take suction from F.O. Sludge tank, F.O. Drain tank and discharge to the deck or the Incinerator Waste Oil tanks.

6.16.03Fuel Oil Purification System


For LS H.F.O., a continuous purification system shall be adopted with the separate feed pump for one of the LS H.F.O. purifier taking suction from one of the LS H.F.O. settling tank and discharge through the heater to the purifier.


The purified oil from the purifier shall discharge to one of the LS H.F.O. service tank and the excess purified oil shall overflow from the service tank back to the settling tank.


One of the LS H.F.O. purifier shall serve for the purification of M.G.O. by taking suction from the M.G.O. settling tank and discharge to the purifier. The purified oil shall be discharged to the M.G.O. service tank.


Sludge and water removed from the oil shall be led to F.O. sludge tank.

6.16.04Main Engine Fuel Oil Service System


A pressurized fuel oil supply module system shall be provided for main engine.


Fuel oil from heavy fuel oil or M.G.O. service tanks shall be drawn to the M/E F.O. Supply module via a change over valve. The M/E F.O. Supply module shall then supply fuel oil to the Main Engine fuel oil inlet.


Return oil from main engine shall flow to mixing chamber or to the H.F.O. service tank.


The system should be designed and constructed to meet as per 1.5%low sulphur fuel oil as MARPOL Annex VI requirement.

6.16.05Auxiliary Engine Fuel System


The generator engines shall be capable of directly started and stopped by using heavy fuel oil supplied via a G/E fuel oil supply module. However marine gas oil shallbe supplied for cold starting and prolong period of low load condition by a M.G.O. booster pump.


M.G.O. / LS H.F.O. change over shall be done manually.


Fuel oil system shall be provided according to maker’s standard.


Fuel oil from heavy fuel oil or M.G.O.service tanks shall be be drawn tothe G/E fuel oil supply module via a change over valve. The G/E F.O. Supply module shall then supply fuel oil to the generator diesel engines fuel oil inlet.


Return oil from thegenerator diesel enginesshall flow to mixing chamber orto the LS H.F.O. service tank.

6.16.06Boiler Fuel Oil System


The composite boiler shall be arranged for burning heavy fuel oil, while MGO supply shall be arranged during start up.


The system shall be as per Maker’s standard.


6.16.07Incinerator Fuel oil System


Marine gas oil pilot burner shall be arranged from the Incinerator marine gas oil service tank. Waste oil burning system shall be arranged according to maker’s standard.

6.16.08Emergency Diesel Generator Engine Fuel Oil System


Fuel system for emergency diesel generator engine shall be arranged according to maker’s standard.

6.17    LUB. OIL SYSTEM

6.17.01General


Lub. oil system for main engine shall be arranged for main engine bearing, camshaft and piston cooling according to Maker’s standard.


Lub. oil system for stern tube shall be arranged.


Purifier for lubricating oil shall be installed according to main engine and aux. engine maker’s recommendation.

6.17.02Lub. Oil Filling Transfer and Drain System


Lubricating oil shall be filled into the storage tanks through filling pipeson upper deck by gravity.


Separate filling connections on both port and starboard side for each grade of lubricant such as main engine system oil, cylinder oil and auxiliary engine system oil shall be provided.


The lubricating oil shall be led to respective sump tank from storage tank by gravity. A test/sample valve shall be provided before filling to sump tank.


L.O. transfer pump shall take suction from main and auxiliary lub. oil storage tanks, main and aux. lub. oil sump tanks, main and aux. lub. oil settling tanks, stern tube lub. oil drain tank, and discharge to the main and aux. settling tanks and to deck connection.


Drain line from the equipment shall be connected to the L.O. drain tank.


Drain from the scavenging box of the main engine shall be led the scavenging box drain tank directly and then shifted to the waste oil tank by the sludge pump.

6.17.03Lub. Oil Purification System


Continuous purification system shall be adopted for the main engine L.O. sump tank.


One purifier shall take suction from main engine lub. oil sump tank and discharge to the purifier via the steam heater. The purified oil shall be returned to the main engine lub. oil sump tank.


One of the lub. oil purifier shall be used for the purification of the aux. engine lub. oil system on a batch basis.

.

The purifiers shall also take suction from the following tanks:


Main engine L.O. settling tank

Aux. engine lub oil settling tank


The purifier shall discharge clean oil to all suction tank except main lub. oil storage tank and auxiliary engine lub. oil storage tank.


Water and sludge separated from oil shall be led to the L.O. sludge tank.

6.17.04Lub. Oil Supply System


Main L.O. pump shall take suction from main engine lub. oil sump tank and discharge through the lub. oil cooler and the lub. oil filter to main engine. A branch line shall be led to the steady bearing and return to the sump tank.


Separate L. O. systems shall be provided forM/E and G/Es.


Cylinder oil measuring tank shall be filled by Cyl. O. shift pump from the cylinder oil storage tanks. A cylinder oil shift hand pump shall be provided as a standby.


A cylinder oil shift pump shall be provided as a standby.


One Cylinder oil tank shall be used during Main Engine operation on MGO.


Cylinderoil measuring tank shall be located according to main engine maker’s recommendation.


Auxiliary engines shall have its own lubricating oil system consisting of engine driven lub. oil pump and built-in lub. oil cooler (or independent lub. oil system as per maker’s standard)

6.17.05Stern Tube Lub. Oil System


Forced circulating lub. oil system shall be provided for stern tube.


L.O. system for stern tube seal shall be arranged according to maker’s standard.

6.18    COOLING WATER SYSTEM

6.18.01General

A central cooling system shall be provided for main engine, auxiliary engines and other essential auxiliary machinery.


The central cooling system shall be divided into seawater system and fresh water system.


The central coolers shall be designed with cooling seawater inlet temperature of 32o C and LT. freshwater temperature of 36 0C.

6.18.02Seawater Cooling System

The main seawater cooling system shall consist of


    Three (3) Main S.W. cooling pumps, each of 50% capacity

    Two (2) central fresh water coolers


Two of the Main seawater cooling pumpsshall be used for the cooling the LT fresh water of central coolers during normal sea going condition, with one pump at stand-by.


One of the Main sea water cooling pumpsshall be used for harbour services. with two pumps at stand-by.


One (1) set of strainer shall be arranged at each sea chest inlet. Strainer elements in seawater cooling system shall be made of stainless steel and body of strainer shall be of steel plate with rubber lining at inside.

Main cooling seawater pumps shall take suction from the cross connection main line and discharge to the central coolers, and then directly overboard.

Overboard discharge shall be fitted directly to shell with spigot or distance piece.

Thickness of spigot shall be in accordance with the requirements of the Classification Society.

The seawater ejector pump for fresh water generator shall take suction from main sea water pipe and discharge to heat exchanger and ejectors of the fresh water generator, and then overboard.


One of the bilge, fire & G.S. pumps shall serve as standby for the F.W.Generator ejector pump.


Marine growth prevention unit shall be provided to treat seawater in the sea cheststrainer.

6.18.03Fresh Water Cooling System

The systems shall operate with inhibited fresh water.


Filling and make up the fresh water systemsshall be provided from the domestic fresh water hydrophore system.


Low Temperature Fresh Water Cooling System:


The following main equipment shall be included in LT FW cooling system (M/E, G/E and Auxiliary system):


* Three (3) LT Main FW pumps (each of 50% capacity)

* One (1) Jacket FW cooler for M/E

* One (1) Lubricating oil cooler for M/E

* Thermostatic valve for low temperature circuit

* One expansion tank for LT FW system


The LT FW cooling system for M/E shall be circulating through the main engine scavenge air cooler, LO cooler and jacket water cooler.


The LT FW cooling system for the auxiliaries shall be circulating through the generator engines,AHU condensers; air conditioning units in ECR&galley; provision refrigeration plant condensers; main air compressors and atmospheric condenser, etc.


The low temperature cooling water circuits shall be served by two(2) of the LT FW cooling pumps during normal sea going condition, with one pump as stand-by.


One of the LT FW cooling pumps shall serve all auxiliaries during harbour service, with two pumps as stand-by.


Automatic temperature control valves shall be installed as required.


High Temperature Cooling Water System for M/E:


The following main equipment shall be included in the HT FW cooling system for M/E


• Two (2) M/E HT fresh water pumps

• One (1) M/E Jacket fresh water cooler

* One (1) HT FW expansion tank

* One (1) HT fresh water preheating pump

* One (1) steam preheater for HT fresh water system


Two (2) M/E HT fresh water pumps shall be provided to circulate the HT cooling water through the main engine cooling water jacket. The pumps shall be so dimensioned that one pump shall be sufficient in service to cover the maximum fresh water demand at CMCR condition during sea going.


One (1) of the two M/E HT fresh water pumps shall be set for automatic stand-by.


High Temperature Cooling Water System for G/E


Fresh water cooling system for the generator engines shall be provided according to generator engine maker’s recommendation.



The air vent line of each generator engine fresh water cooling system shall be connected to the HT FW expansion tank.


The capacity and position of expansion tank shall be arranged in accordance with main engine and generator engine maker’s recommendation.

6.18.04Main Engine Air Cooler Cleaning System


For main engine air cooler cleaning, one (1) set of air cooler cleaning water circulating pump and chemical cleaning water tank shall be provided as engine maker’s recommendation.

6.19    COMPRESSED AIR SYSTEM (STARTING, GENERAL PURPOSE AND CONTROL AIR SYSTEM)

6.19.01General


The air compressors and air reservoirs shallhave sufficient capacity for starting the main engine and auxiliary engines, and for supplying the necessary air for general services and control air service.


Air reservoirs shall be of cylindrical welded construction of steel plate in compliance with the requirement of Classification Society.



For starting the main engine and auxiliary engines, compressed air of 30 bar shall be used.


For general purpose and control air system, compressed air of 7 bar shall be used.

6.19.02Starting Air System


Compressed air from the two (2) main air compressors shall be led to the main air reservoirs.


Compressed air from auxiliary air compressor shall be led to the auxiliary air reservoir.


Starting air to main engine and auxiliary engines to be distributed from the main air reservoirs.


Generator enginesshall be also supplied from the auxiliary air reservoir for dead ship starting.


One (1) line with non-return valve shall be provided from main air reservoir to auxiliary air reservoir for charging.

6.19.03Service Air System


Service air for ship general service shall be supplied from deck service air compressor,through a pressure reducing valve, and led to deck air reservoir through a pressure reducing valve.

Working air for air tools and sea chest blowing shall be of 7 bar. (30bar reduced to 7 bar)

6.19.04Control Air Supply System


The working pressure for the control air supply shall be of 7 bar.


The air from main air reservoir shall be led to the control air reservoir through a pressure reducing valve and shall be used as control air supply via the control air dryer.


Control air dryer of refrigerated type shall be provided for removing the moisture in the control air.

6.20EXHAUAST GAS SYSTEM

6.20.01General


All exhaust gas pipes shall be made of steel, fitted with expansion joints and shall be rigidly secured with brackets.


Mild steel flanges shall be provided.


All exhaust gas pipes shall be led to the top of the funnel.


All precautions shall be taken to eliminate heat radiation from exhaust pipes to the surrounding accommodation, stores etc. as far as possible.


Necessary drains from the exhaust gas pipes shall be arranged.

6.20.02Exhaust Gas System for main engine


Exhaust gas pipe from the main engine shall be led to the top of the funnel through the exhaust gas part of the composite boiler acting as silencer. No by-pass pipe shall be provided.

6.20.03Exhaust gas system for auxiliary engine


Separate exhaust gas pipes with silencer, from each auxiliary engine shall be arranged and shall be led to the top of the funnel.


G/E exhaust gas pipes and silencers shall be provided with water drainpipes.

6.20.04Exhaust gas system for composite boiler, etc.


Exhaust gas pipe for the oil fired side of the composite boiler shall be led to the top of the funnel.


Exhaust gas pipe from the incinerator shall be led to the top of the funnel.

6.21    STEAM, CONDENSATE, FEED WATER SYSTEM

6.21.01General

Capacity of feed water filter tank shall be according to the boiler maker’s recommendation and system requirement.

6.21.02Saturated Steam System

Steam system shall consist of 7bar systems and steam to be supplied for necessary services as mentioned below.


The surplus steam generated by the exhaust gas section of the boiler shall be automatically dumped to the atmospheric condenser at normal sea going.


7 barsaturated steam shall be supplied to the following services.

H.F.O. purifier heaters

M/E F.O. booster module

G/E F.O. booster module

H.F.O. settling tanks

H.F.O. service tanks

H.F.O. overflow tank

F.O. drain tank

H.F.O. Sludge tank

L.O. sludge tank

Main L.O. sump tank

M/E L.O. settling tank

G/E L.O. settling tank

L.O. purifier heaters

Waste oil tank for incinerator

Oily bilge tank

Bilge holding tank

Oily water separator (as per maker’s standard)

Steam tracing for F.O. system*

M/E air cooler cleaning tank

Feed water filter tank

HFO Bunker tanks

Calorifier

Air condition unit

Living quarter service (if any)

E/R Sea chests

E/R general service

Main engine fire extinguishing system

    * The following pipelines shall be traced with steam heating pipe:

1. Pipes of main engine F.O. service system

2. Pipes of generator engine F.O. service system

3. Pipes of boiler F.O. service system

4. Suction & delivery pipes of heavy fuel oil transfer pump

    5. Suction and delivery pipes of F.O. purifiers

6.21.03Exhaust Steam System

Relieving line to atmosphere shall be suitably arranged from the safety valves of composite boiler and safety valves after pressure reducing valve and shall be led to safe location.

6.21.04Condensate and Steam Drain System

Condensate from atmospheric condenser shall be led to the feed water filter tank by gravity through the observation tank.


Steam drain from oil heating coils, oil pre-heaters and other oil tank heating services shall be led to the feed water filter tank through the observation tank and atmospheric condenser. Other clean steam drain shall be led to the feed water filter tank through observation tank and the atmospheric condenser.


Leaked drain to the bilge well shall be led to local scupper.

6.21.05Feed Water System

The feed water system shall consist of two (2) feed water pumps for composite boiler, one (1) feed water filter tank and one (1) observation tank.


Make-up feed water shall be supplied to feed filter tank water from fresh water distill tank or fresh water tanks respectively.

The feed water chemical treatment accessories fitting equipment shall be provided for feed water treatment.

Feed water salinity meter shall be provided.

6.22    DISTILLED, MAKE-UP WATER AND SANITARY SYSTEM

6.22.01Fresh Water Generator


The waste heat from main engine jacket cooling water shall be used for heating and the distilled water shall be cooled by seawater from the sea water ejector pump.


A dosing system shall be provided at the F.W. generator seawater feed lineaccording to maker’s standard.


The distilling pump shall take suction from the condenser and discharge to the distilled water tank, the fresh water tanks or to the washing water tank when needed for tank washing.

6.22.02Hydrophore Units And Sterilizer


The hydrophore tank shall be of welded steel construction and interior surface shall be coated with pure epoxy paint.


Fresh water from fresh water hydrophore unit shall be supplied to wash basins, laundry, galley, hot water system, engine cooling system, boiler system and etc.


One of the fresh water pumps shall draw water from fresh water tanks and deliver through a non-return valve to the fresh water hydrophore tank.


Cold fresh water from fresh water hydrophore tank shall be led directly to accommodation, calorifier, sanitary and necessaries tanks, and one line shall supply through sterilizer to drinking water fountains.


Automatic pressure control shall be provided to start and stop the pump as required to maintain pressure in the hydrophore tank.

6.22.03Calorifier And Hot Water Circulating Pump


One(1) set of calorifier and one (1) set of hot water circulating pump shall be provided for hot water supply.


The calorifier shall be capable of heating quantity of 2.0 m3/hr from 10 to 70oC with cleanliness factor of 90% when supplied with steam.


The inside shell of storage tank of the calorofier shall be of stainless steel.


Material for the heating tube of steam heater shall be in accordance with maker’s standard.


The calorifier shall be arranged for steam heating with thermostatic valve and also electric heating as a reserve.


The hot water circulating pump shall be installed in the return line of the loop system through accommodation and discharge to the calorifier via a non-return valve.

6.22.04Sanitary System


Fresh water shall be used for flushing the toilet and shall be supplied from the fresh water hydrophore system.


A seawater service line with double type blind flange also shall be provided for the toilet flushing system in case of emergency.

6.23    BILGE SYSTEM IN ENGINE ROOM

6.23.01General


Bilge piping shall be arranged according to the requirements of the Classification Society.


Bilge pipes shall have dimensions in accordance with the requirements of the Classification Society.


Independent bilge system for engine room shall be provided.

6.23.02Bilge Piping System In Engine Room


Sludge pump shall take suction from sludge tanks, and discharges to the upper deck and waste oil tank.


The engine room bilge pump shall take suction from bilge holding tank and bilge well, and discharges to oily water separator and hence to International shore Connections on upper deck. Engine room bilge pump priming apparatus shall be provided..


Direct suction from engine room shall be provided as per Class Rules.

6.24SLUDGE AND WASTE OIL BURNING SYSTEM

The incinerator shall be capable of burning oil and waste oil.


The unit shall be of fresh air admixture and shall be arranged for fully automatic operation.


Safety cut out system shall be provided according to maker’s standard.


The Incinerator shall consist of a pilot burner, a liquid waste burner, sight glass, ash box, primary air fan and one (1) waste oil tank with pumping unit.


A control and indicating panel shall be fitted adjacent to the incinerator.

6.25SOIL DRAIN AND DECK SCUPPER SYSTEM

6.25.01General


Sewage treatment plant shall be provided in engine room.


Toilet discharge including scuppers drain in toilets shall be connected to the sewage treatment plant.


Hospital drain including washbasin, washtub and scupper shall be lead to sewage treatment plant directly.


Drainage from wash basin, shower space, bathtub and bathroom shall not be led to the sewage plant unless they are contaminated with toilet drainage.


No sewage shall be disposed in harbour or restricted areas by concerning Authorities in accordance with Regulatory Requirement.


No separate sewage storage tank shall be provided.


Sewage overboard connection shall be arranged below ballast water line.


Discharge Outlet from the Sewage Treatment Plant shall be directed to a Sewage Holding tank for temporary storage, if overboard discharge is prohibited in harbour.





6.26    MISCELLANEOUS

6.26.01Floors, Gratings And Ladders


Platforms, gratings and ladders shall be provided for access, operation and repair of the machinery and other apparatus.


Checkered plates shall be arranged on the lower floor in the engine room, around the main engine and on the walkway for access to other machinery enabling easy patrol inspection for duty engineer where possible.


Maintenance platform shall be provided for pumps and equipment where necessary.


Open gratings, expanded metal and checkered plates shall be appropriately used around composite boiler, passage way, etc., in casing and funnel.


Open grating shall be of fabricated galvanized steel and supported by steel angle frames.


Hinged hand hole covers shall be provided on the floor plate for operating valves and strainers.


The main access grating and ladder shall have a width of about 600 mm in principle.


The slope of the main access ladder shall benot more than 60 degrees to horizontal in general.


The ladders shall be provided with a non-slip type tread and hand rails.


The main ladder shall be provided with a dust plate at the under side if there is a passage under the main ladder.


A vertical ladder shall be provided where the installation of an inclined ladder is impracticable.


The handrails shall be of galv. steel pipes painted same as surrounding including the top rail.


The stanchion shall be of steel pipe for inclined ladders.

6.26.02Sea Chests


The sea chests shall be of welded steel construction with hinged stainless steel grids and a clear area of at least 2 times the cross section area of all the sea suctions.


The grids shall be secured with stainless steel bolts and nuts and shall be so fastened that no part extends past the shell plate.


Each sea chest in engine room shall be provided with a steam and a compressed air blowing connection and the sea suction for the emergency fire pump shall be provided with a compressed air blowing connection only.


The sea chest shall be provided with air and drain holes on the top and bottom sides.


The sea chest fittings shall be designed according to the under water survey of the Class requirements.

6.26.03Overboard Sea Connections


The overboard sea connections shall be steel pipe or fabricated steel plate of suitable thickness in accordance with the requirements of the Classification Society.


The discharge valves shall be arranged under the light load water line in principle.


Overboard discharge connections shall be avoided in and around the lifeboat area and the accommodation ladder.

6.26.04Uptakes And Funnel


(1)    Diesel Engine Exhaust Gas uptake


The exhaust gas uptake from the main engine exhaust gas turbochargersshall be led to the atmosphere through the exhaust gas section of the composite boiler.


The diesel generator engine exhaust gas uptakesshall be led to the atmosphere through the silencers.


Bellows type expansion joint of stainless steel (flange to be steel) to be provided on the exhaust gas uptake of the engines.


The exhaust gas uptake shall be supported from the ship’s structure.


(2)    Composite Boiler Uptake


The composite boiler uptake shall be led from the composite boiler to the atmosphere.


Bellows type expansion joint of stainless steel (flange to be steel) shall be provided on the composite boiler exhaust gas uptake.


(3)    Incinerator Uptake


The waste oil incinerator uptake shall be led from the incinerator to the atmosphere.


Bellows type expansion joint of stainless steel (flange to be steel) shall be provided on the exhaust gas uptake.


(4)    Funnel


A funnel of suitable height and ample size for the pipes and access shall be provided as shown in the General Arrangement Plan.


The funnel shall be kept weather-tight by a horizontal weather shield with access hatch.


The drain from the weather shield shall be led to the weather scupper.


An access hatch shall be provided for the funnel.



(5)    Oil mist chamber


Oil mist from the engine crankcase shall be led to the atmosphere through a mist chamber.


Also, the air vents of heated oil tanks shall be led to the oil mist chamber if necessary. The drainpipe from the mist chamber shall be led to the oily bilge tank.


The oil mist chamber shall be made of steel pipe or fabricated steel plate.

6.26.05Ventilation

The machinery space shall be served by a mechanical ventilation system.


The ventilating fan shall supply fresh air to the operating stations and other necessary places in the engine room through air ducts.

Thickness

Surface

L (mm)


(mm)

Preparation

Accom rectangular Vent

5

L>1500


Ventilating duct shall be made to a round cross section with no coated on spiral duct in accordance with the shipyard’s practice.


Spiral duct shall be of aluminum alloy coated steel, the thickness and installation shall be in accordance with the shipyard's practice.


Rectangular steel duct with the anti-rusted painted on steel plate may be used where necessary.


The height of the vent ducts shall be approx. 2,200 mm from the passage as far as practicable.


The exhaust air from the engine room shall be led to the atmosphere through an opening at the rear wall of the funnel.


The exhaust air opening and fresh air intakes shall be provided with wire pulled type emergency shut-off fire dampers operated from outside of the engine room.


Purifier room exhaust air shall be extracted through independent ducting.

6.26.06Workshops


An engine workshop and an electric workshop shall be arranged in the engine room.


The workshopsshall be isolated by a steel walls.On the side facing the machinery space an entrance door shall be provided.


Drilling machine, grinder, lathe, welding set and etc. shall be arranged in the engine workshop and also a tool locker, work bench, locker and wash basin shall be provided.


Oxygen and acetylene bottles for gas welder shall be arranged on the upper deck inside lockers and two permanent steel pipe lines shall be led from the lockers to the workshop in engine room through a regulating valve and pressure gauge.


A test panel shall be provided in the electric workshop.

6.26.07Welding Area

A welding area shall be provided in the engine workshop with fireproof curtain surrounding it.


An exhaust fan shall be provided for the welding area.

6.26.08Store Room


A storeroom shall be arranged adjacent to the workshops where possible in the engine room


The storeroom shall be isolated by a fenced wall.


Shelves shall be provided in the storeroom for storing spare parts, tools and general equipment.


Boxes for spare parts and tools shall be of steel construction and as provided by the maker’s standard of the subject equipment.

6.26.09Purifier Room

A welded steel constructed purifier room shall be provided in the engine room, with two self-closing doors.


The following auxiliaries shall be arranged in the room as far as practicable.


LS HFO Purifiers, L.O. Purifers &Purifier heaters

LS HFO Purifier supply pumps

M/E F.O. supply module

G/E F.O. supply module

Boiler F.O. supply pumps

Boiler F.O. heater(if needed)

Purifier cleaning table

Hand basin

Lifting beam and trolley

6.26.10Tanks


The tanks of large capacity shall be, in general, integral with the hull construction while small sized tanks shall be independent of the hull construction.


All tanks shall be of welded construction made of steel plate and shall be provided with stiffeners, if necessary.


Each tank shall be equipped with necessary fittings, such as a sounding device, air vent, manhole or handhole, etc. Overflow and draining device shall also be fitted where applicable.


The size of the air vent and overflow shall be in accordance with the requirements of the Classification Society.

6.26.11Lifting Gear

(1)    Main Engine


Overhead crane shall be installed above the main engine and shall be supported by two side-rails laid across fore and aft of the engine room.

End stoppers shall be provided to prevent over traveling.


The overhead crane shall be able to reach heavy spare parts stored in the vicinity of the main engine.


The overhead crane shall be controlled by a portable control box with flexible cable.


HoistingElectric motor driven (two speed)

TravelingElectric motor driven

TraversingElectric motor driven


(2)    Main Diesel Generator Engine


Fixed I-beams and trolley shall be provided for overhauling the generator engines.


(3)    Shafting


Fixed I-beam and three geared trolleysshall be provided for withdrawing the propeller shaft inboard.


(4)    Purifier


Fixed I-beam and a trolley shall be provided for overhauling the purifiers.


(5)    Workshop and Store room


Fixed I-beam and a trolley shall be arranged for workshop and storeroom


(6)    Other Machinery


Fixed I-beam and a trolley shall be arrangedabove large pump area for maintenance of electric motors and pumps.


Eye-platesshall be suitably fitted for motors, pumps, heat exchangers and heavy strainers about 45 kg and above.


Hoisting space for lifting spare parts from engine room to upper deck and vice versa shall be well considered.


I-Beam monorail to be extended in adjacent to engine room hatch and carry on to reach to workshop and store room space.

6.26.12Colour Scheme of Equipment/Piping


The colour of finished coat for machinery external surface shall be in accordance with the followings.


machinery including electric motor shall be of maker’s standard.


All piping system shall be provided with colour label scheme by means of colour tape.


The scheme shall be submitted to Buyer for approval.

6.26.13Insulation

(1)    General


The surfaces having normal operating temperatures above 60oC shall be insulated, except valves and flanges, where required, for maintaining internal fluid temperature and for personal protection.


Insulation of all machinery such as diesel engine, composite boiler, incinerator, heater, calorifier and etc., shall be in accordance with each maker’s standard practice.


Wherever insulated piping contains flanges, fittings and valves, the ends of the insulation shall be suitably terminated to permit free removal of bolts and to allow for movement of the pipe on its hangers.


Insulation materials for vertical exhaust gas uptakes shall be fastened on suitable stoppers (protecting rings), which are directly welded on the uptakes.


Exhaust gas uptakes in the funnel shall be insulated up to about 500 mm down from the top of funnel.


Steam safety valve discharge to the atmosphere and open drain piping shall be insulated only where it is necessary for protection of personnel.


H.F.O. lines except H.F.O. filling, drain, overflow and air vent lines shall be steam traced with insulation.


Tanks below the floor shall not be insulated, in principle, except where it is necessary for protection of personnel and reducing heat losses. Steam pipe below the floor shall be insulated.


The cold S.W. & F.W. pipes overhead M/E and G/E shall be insulated with the glass cloth for sweat protection.


Feed water filter tank with condensate observation tank shall be insulated with glass wool of 25mm thickness and covered with cloth of silver color.



(2)Insulation of Exhaust Gas Uptake


Insulation to be applied as follows:



Insulation


Kind of Engine

Thickness (mm)

Material

Cover

Main Engine

Pipe75

Flange75

Glass cloth

+

Galvanized steel

plate 0.8mm thick

Generatordiesel engine and composite boiler

Pipe & flange50

Rock wool on straight pipes or glass wool on joints

Galvanized steel

plate 0.6mm thick

Incinerator and Emergency diesel engine

50

+

glass cloth

Do


Main engine exhaust manifold and silencers for generator diesel engine shall be insulated in accordance with the maker's standard.


All final layer of glass cloth to be sewn up finish.


(3)    Insulation of steam piping


Pipes, flanges, valves and fittings of all steam and exhaust piping shall be

insulated as follows:-


Name of piping

(4)    Insulation of Steam Drain Piping

    

Drain piping shall be insulated in the same manner as for steam piping.


All small bore steam drain piping shall be wrapped (spiral wrapped) with glass fiber tape.


No insulation shall be applied on piping of less than 25 mm and below the floor plate in engine room which do not pose a risk to personal injury.


(5)    Insulation of Water Piping


Cooling fresh water piping shall not be insulated.


Hot fresh water shall be insulated where required for personal protection.


Following piping shall be insulated in the same manner as for steam piping:


Composite boiler blow-off piping in front of the boiler and where subject to handling.


The drain pipe of Refrigerated Chamber



(6)Oil Piping


Heated oil piping having temperature above 60oC shall be insulated .For easy of maintence and visual leackge inspection, the valves and the flanges should not be insulated.


(7)Insulation of Tank


The heavy fuel oil settling tank, heavy fuel oil service tank and F.O. overflow tank, main and auxiliary L.O. settling tanks shall be insulated with 25mm thick glass wool or rock wool and covered with 0.6mm thick galvanized sheet steel. Suitable removable mats shall be provided for manholes of the tanks.


F.O. bunker tanks shall not be insulated.

6.26.14Engine Control Room

(1)    General


A sound and heat insulated engine control room shall be provided above the workshop in the engine room.


A package type air conditioning unit shall be installed inside of the engine control room for cooling of the engine control room.


Double glass windows and two insulated doors shall be provided for the engine control room.


The floor shall be covered with removable, non-slip rubber insulating deck covering.


(2)Equipment in Engine Control Room


One (1)        Engine control console

One (1)        Main switchboard

One (1)        Group starter panel for essential auxiliaries

One (1)        package type unit cooler

One (1)        Portable CO2 fire extinguisher


One (1)        Bookrack


One (1)        Whiteboard


Three (3)    chairs

One (1)        Life jacket case

One (1)         Writing desk

One (1)         Inclinometer

One (1)         Filing cabinet

One (1)         Refrigerator about 60 Liters

One (1)         Tea table

Two transformers shall be installed in the transformer store outside the engine control room.

6.26.15Gauge


Pressure gauges, thermometers, gauge glasses and sight glasses shall be provided in necessary parts.


The scales of the gauges shall be of SI units.


The gauges provided by the Makers shall be in accordance with the Maker’s standards.


One three-way cock (socket type with plug) use for checking pressure gauge without stopping the plant to be provided for the following points (near to the gauge):


F.O. inlet of M/E

L.O. inlet of M/E

Cooling F.W. inlet of M/E

Outlet of back-flushing filter of M/E

Outlet of back-flushing filter of A/E


For temperature measurement along the pipes, thermo-pockets to be provided allow changing or calibration of the thermometer without stopping the plant.

6.26.16Name and Caution Plate


Name plates and caution plates shall be made of brass, stainless steel or plastic according to Builder’s standard.


The nameplates and caution plates provided by the Makers shall be according to Maker’s standard.

6.26.17Installation


Generally, machinery and equipment shall be installed directly on deck except the major machinery with prime mover such as the main engine and the generator sets which shall be provided with foundations.


Suitable deck reinforcements shall be provided according with Class requirements and Builder’s practice.


Fully penetration welding or double continuous welding shall be applied for the main engine foundation and shaft bearing foundation in accordance with Class requirements and Builder’s practice.


Resin chocks shall be used for main engine.


Foundation areas under M/E, G/E, Composite Boiler, and other auxiliary/equipment or other areas where it is hard to access for maintenance shall be applied epoxy paint (200u) prior to installation.

6.27    SPARE PARTS, ACCESSORIES AND TOOLS


Spare parts and tools for all machinery and equipments shall be furnished in accordance with Maker’s standard and the Classification Society's Rules


6.27.01Spare Parts and Accessories


All spare parts and tools shall be suitably stored on board. Heavy spare parts shall be mounted on suitable brackets or straps and fastened to the hull construction near the respective machinery as far as practicable.


Spare parts for shafting and miscellaneous are shown as follows:

The quantity shown is supplied per vessel.


(1)    Shafting and Propeller

Quantity

Two for each size


Tools

    (2)    Miscellaneous


Safety valve of main vessel

1 set

Safety valve of vessel for quick-closing valve

1 set

6.27.02Engineer’s General Tools and Equipment


All the tools and equipment to be provided as per builder’s standard.

7.    ELECTRIC PART

7.1    ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT AND SYSTEM

7.1.01General


All electrical equipment and installation shall be in accordance with this Specification, Builder’s practice, Rules and Regulations mentioned in the General Part of these Specifications and IEC (International Electro-technical Commission)unless specified otherwise.


Installation of electric equipment and wiring necessities by structural, joiner, or machinery works mentioned in other parts of the Specification shall be provided.


The types and construction of electrical equipment incorporated or packed with the appliance shall be in accordance with the maker’s standards unless specially described, and may be changed by their maker’s due to type or model changes.


In general, cable terminals shall be of solderless type.


All electrical systems and equipment shall be easily accessible and installed in well ventilated positions as far as practicable and shall not be exposed to the risk of mechanical damage from water, steam, or oil, and clear of inflammable materials or gases.


Where necessarily exposed to such a risk, the equipment shall be properly protected.


Where electric equipments are installed in thehazardous area such as battery room or paint room, the equipment shall be of explosion proof type or intrinsically safe type.


All electrical equipment and control panel shall be provided with earth connection according to Rule’s requirement and/or maker’s recommendation.





7.1.02Operation Conditions


(1)    Temperature


In general, electric equipment shall be designed for the following ambient temperature.


Seawater    32°C

Air    45°C


Where ambient temperature is in excess of the above described values, the maximum temperature rise shall not exceed the value specified by the Rules.



(2)    Voltage and Frequency


All electric equipment to function at variations of:


Frequency:    5% under the steady load condition

10% under the transient load condition within 5sec.

Voltage:        +6%, -10% under the steady load condition

20% under the transient load condition within 1.5sec.


(3)    Environment Condition


Inclination of ship


Heeling15o (for Propulsion and Aux. Mach.)

22.5o (for Safety equip and Switchgear)

Rolling    22.5o

Trimming    5o (for Propulsion and Aux. Mach)

    10o (for Safety equip and Switchgear)

Pitching    7.5o (for Propulsion and Aux. Mach)

    10o (for Safety equip and Switchgear)


7.1.03Phase Identification


Phase identification of buses, supply terminals, and color coding of power supply conductors, except for lighting branch circuits shall be in accordance with the International standard.


(1) Alternating current circuit


Phase symbol

Load side

Color

(2) Direct current circuit

The main distribution system shall be three (3) phase, three (3) wires, alternating current system, and each conductor shall be thoroughly insulated on board.
